—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It follows reports in today's press that Australia is to host an international conference on chemical weapons. Can the Minister report to the House the purpose of Australia hosting this conference?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia will host a major international chemical weapons conference later this year. The conference will bring together governments and representatives of the international chemical industry. It will discuss the growing problems of the trade in feedstocks, plant, equipment and knowhow which are being diverted to the production of chemical weapons. The idea of the conference followed discussions between Senator Gareth Evans and United States Secretary of State Baker about how to build on the momentum created by the Paris conference on this matter in January this year. It is interesting to note this comment on Australia's decision to host the conference, made yesterday by the Secretary of State:

ANSWER.PARA: For a number of years, Australia has played a leading role internationally in trying to prevent the spread of chemical weapons, including as the leader of the Australian group of Western chemical producing states.

Australia has worked very actively with other governments to establish barriers against inadvertent involvement of several chemical industries in other nations' chemical weapons programs. This has included, firstly, convening consultations among 19 Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries, known as the Aus Group, to develop coordinated export controls over chemical weapons preservers; secondly, developing consultations with regional governments to prevent the spread of chemical weapons in our neighbourhood and building a constructive working dialogue with Australia's own chemical industry. Like the Paris conference, the proposed conference will be supportive of the aims of the chemical weapons convention under negotiation at the Geneva Conference on Disarmament. A comprehensive global convention banning chemical weapons once and for all remains Australia's prime objective in this pressing area of disarmament. The fact that we will be hosting the conference referred to by the honourable member is a further reflection of our leadership role in the international efforts against the spread of chemical weapons.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. What training benefits, if any, will the Australian Defence Force derive from exercise Kangaroo 89? Is the cost of that exercise justified?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen in debate in this House comment by the Opposition that the cancellation of Kangaroo 89 would be a desirable thing on the ground that strategic circumstances have changed since the planning took place. What that demonstrates is that in this critical area of defence policy, in which it does not have a shadow Cabinet Minister, it is as ignorant as it is on every other major area of policy that the Parliament is obliged to deal with. The point about the Kangaroo 89 exercise is that it is about the testing of our capability to deal with low level contingencies that might arise with little warning. The point about that exercise that provoked the comments of the Opposition was a discussion in this place of the fact that we do not plan our defence forces on the basis of the least likely threat, which is a massive invasion of this country. What Kangaroo 89 is directed at is based on not only the intelligence advice that we have received since we have been in office but also intelligence advice that our opponents received when they were in office, that is, the probability or possibility of a low level of threat arising in a very short period. In doing that, our defence forces maintain and develop their capabilities to act over very long distances indeed. So in testing our capacity to defend against low level harassment in our area of direct military interest-that is a threat directly aimed at us-we also test our capacity to operate elsewhere if need be, and that includes operations outside the immediate area of this country. So in terms of all the likely low level contingencies that are going to arise, Kangaroo 89 exercises our capacity to deal with that.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that a number of defence exercises have been cancelled in order to make up the numbers engaged in this exercise. In fact, something like $70m worth of defence exercises has been cancelled in order to pay for more than $90m worth of exercises associated with this. Why would they be cancelled? Because instead of exercising the individual elements of the armed forces singly, as would be the case on those particular exercises, they are now exercised in a joint and combined fashion. They have maintained and developed, in terms of their individual unit skills, exactly the same sort of benefits that they would have had from those exercises that they did on their own. They have the additional benefits of added resources in this exercise and an opportunity to operate as combined arms. If Opposition members want to see the genesis of this Kangaroo 89 exercise, they can go back into the exercises organised when they were in office in the early part of the 1980s. We have been extending those series of exercises, developing them and refining them.

It is a very strange thing-because the Opposition is yet to release its defence policy-that what is now emerging from the Opposition is no discussion relevant to either the intelligence assessments related to this country or the strategic planning that occurred under both the Opposition and us, but some sort of wild throwback to the 1960s, to an era that has long since disappeared. One can only guess why this should be the case and why there should be calls for cutting out the most important exercise, albeit one of a series building up to this point in a way that started under the Opposition. There can be only one reason for cutting out this exercise and that is that the Opposition must be opening up ways for defence cuts. It is true that if all Opposition members wish to do is to show the flag, if they do not wish to be serious about the defence of this country, they do not need a dozen frigates, or whatever, as they can probably make do with two or three; they certainly do not need the air defence capabilities that this country is building up with FA18 aircraft based across the north and F111 bombers; and they do not need an army the size of 32,000. They can do all of that if they want to and show the flag around the neighbourhood with an awful lot less than half of the type of military capability that we have in this country. We have major military capabilities in this country. We are developing those capabilities further and we are expanding them significantly. The fact is that our expansions and the expenditures that we make on them are directed towards detailed strategic planning. Obviously, Opposition members are incapable of that. They are incapable of understanding a strategic basis for a defence policy. They are incapable of understanding an intelligence estimate to go into that strategic basis, and they are incapable of devising a defence strategy that gives this country the security it needs.

ANSWER.PARA: If the National Party is having a problem with policy formation it is hardly being assisted by the farm groups themselves. —The Minister for Defence will be aware of my concern for the conditions of service personnel and their families. I ask the Minister whether the Government will be declaring the peacekeeping force to Namibia operational for the purpose of repatriation benefits.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his question. This concern for defence personnel is well known in this place. The answer to the honourable gentleman's question is yes. The Prime Minister, in the course of his statement to the House yesterday, said:

ANSWER.PARA: Repatriation benefits appropriate to the tasks and hazards encountered will also be provided.

Having regard to the risks confronting the peacekeeping force-risks which were well canvassed during the Prime Minister's statement and the ensuing debate-I can confirm that the force will be regarded as being on operational service. The Government will push through the necessary legislative amendments during the current sittings. I am confident that we will have the cooperation of the Opposition, given what was said in the course of debate yesterday. In the interim, my colleague the Minister for Veterans' Affairs has gazetted the force to provide it with the coverage that normally applies to peacekeepers.

Some honourable members may not fully understand the implications of that decision. It is, after all, something that no previous government has done in respect of an Australian peacekeeping force as listed in schedule 3 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act. In basic terms if means that members of this force will be entitled to the full range of benefits and entitlements available under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. For example, they will be eligible for service pension and certain associated allowances. An appropriate amendment will also be made to the Defence Service Homes Act to extend coverage to the small number of Namibian peacekeepers who would not otherwise quality for a defence service homes loan.

In coming to this decision in respect of this force, the Government should not be regarded as setting a precedent for the conditions which will apply to any future peacekeeping force. Those conditions will have to be assessed at the time and on the basis of the likely danger. Nor should it be assumed that it presages a review on our part of the conditions that applied to previous forces. The point is that what we are doing in the exercise we are going through, in determining the conditions of the service personnel that are going to Namibia, is identifying them as a peacekeeping force that is distinctly different from those in which we have been involved in the past, with some functions-particularly given the nature of those troops as engineers-that are more roughly the equivalent of the sorts of experiences of troops who were deployed to theatres such as Borneo and Vietnam. That would not be the normal condition of peacekeepers. We would not regard those currently engaged in peacekeeping operations elsewhere-for example, in Iran, Iraq or the Lebanon-as operating under the same conditions.

An essential difference here-this will in some form or another feature in the amendments to the Act-is the fact that this force has been designated as required to be armed. Whilst out on operations the soldiers will carry weapons. That is, of course, a very considerable distinction between their situation and that of the other peacekeeping operations that I have referred to. In order to be able to do this, to demonstrate that it is a one-off and not a general extension of conditions which appropriately apply to return of service in operational theatres in areas where there is not, in our view, the requirement to do that, we will require amendments to the Act and they will be brought forward.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS: SALE OF AIRCRAFT

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the Opposition's interest today in aviation, I ask: Can the Minister for Transport and Communications advise the House of the circumstances surrounding the sale of an F28 jet by his Department in 1987?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that my Department in 1987 sold an F28 aircraft to Ansett Transport Industries. Of course, 1987 was well before I became Minister for Transport and Communications. The disposal of the aircraft followed the Department's decision in 1985 to replace one of its F28 aircraft with a smaller, more efficient, less noisy jet aircraft. The action was principally designed to reduce the cost of the Department's jet aircraft flying program. In order to identify the most suitable aircraft type, in October 1985 the Department publicly invited registrations of interest from aircraft suppliers for the exchange of one of the Department's F28s for a small twin jet aircraft. Nine organisations responded to the request. Evaluation of the expressions of interest led to the BAE125 aircraft being considered the most suitable replacement for the F28.

ANSWER.PARA: On 26 October the Department decided to invite public tenders for the provision of a BAE125 in exchange for the F28. Advertisements were placed in the Australian national press and the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette, and copies of the tender documents were forwarded to Australian Government representatives in Washington and London for regional distribution. In addition, invitations were issued directly to about 20 companies. Ansett Transport Industries (Operations) Pty Ltd was the successful tenderer. I am advised that the tender procedures complied with Finance regulations and that the then Department of Local Government and Administrative Services was consulted. It considered the proposal reasonable and that it would be in the best interests of the Commonwealth to accept the Ansett offer.

The Department took over the BAE125 aircraft and released the F28 to Ansett during December of 1987. I understand that Ansett subsequently sold the aircraft overseas-for what price, of course, we do not know, although I have noticed that Mr McMahon, the General Manager of Ansett, was reported in the press today as saying that the aircraft was sold for a small profit. The allegations made in a question yesterday by the honourable member for Richmond that there was no tender process and that the Department of Administrative Services procedures had not been adhered to were quite incorrect. Everything was absolutely above board. All of the appropriate procedures were adhered to. I suggest that the honourable member, instead of engaging in scuttlebutt, get on with the real issues.

—The paper is confidential.
—The paper is confidential. The Minister was also asked whether he would table the advertisements.

I confirm that such a facility, which is the type of facility on which I have received advice, could possibly be constructed within four years.

—The Prime Minister will be aware that the oldest political party in Australia will celebrate its centenary in two years' time. It was, as all honourable members will know, an aftermath of the debilitating shearers' strike in 1891. He would also be aware that the first branch meeting was held under the Tree of Knowledge at Barcaldine. That is when the word `masochism' was introduced into the English language. For some years now members of the local community have been working very hard to establish an interpretive centre to commemorate the early pioneers, the shearers and those who founded the Australian Labor Party. They have sought, so far without success, financial support from both State and Federal governments. It would appear that there may be some reluctance on the Government's part to provide that assistance because of possible criticism from the non-Labor side of politics. I ask the Prime Minister: Will he give consideration to this request and, if necessary, discuss the matter with the Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the National Party on the grounds that, while the shearers strike and the Tree of Knowledge are an important part of the Labor Party's history, they are also a very important part of the nation's history? I would hope that when, in the near future, the Liberal Party has its fiftieth birthday and the National Party its seventy-fifth, the Labor Party would similarly acknowledge their contribution to our heritage.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think everyone will agree that the town of Barcaldine in central Queensland has a special place in the history of the Australian Labor movement and, indeed, the Australian nation. There, in June 1891, shearers did meet under what has become known as the Tree of Knowledge and, with the imminent collapse of their great strike that was being conducted at that time, they determined to pursue their just cause through the ballot box. The aspirations of those bush workers merged with those of other working men and women throughout Australia. As a result of that impetus, we then saw the birth of the Australian Labor Party. Out of the adversity of the defeat which they then suffered came hope for future success and for ultimate progress towards the creation in this country of a fairer society.

ANSWER.PARA: The shire of Barcaldine is proposing to mark the centenary of this event, as the honourable member suggested, with the establishment of an interpretation centre.

TALK.START.PARA: —We need an interpreter to understand you.

—If the honourable member wants to knock the shire, that is his business. We will duly note that he is knocking their suggestion. It is the suggestion of the shire, and we will convey the honourable member's attitude, that he is knocking their suggestion. I was first approached by them in 1986 with a request for assistance for a project to mark the shearers strike of 1891. There were subsequent meetings with several of my Ministers, and the Deputy Prime Minister unveiled the Tree of Knowledge monument in 1987 at Barcaldine. The monument was built with Commonwealth assistance of $20,040. The Government has provided a range of other assistance measures: $25,000 towards two archaeological surveys of the site, and $20,000 towards a consultant study on the viability of an interpretation centre.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the provision of further Commonwealth funds, the Government's current guidelines restrict the funding of museum capital works to Commonwealth establishments. This position has been advised by the present Minister for Arts and Territories and I believe it was advised by the honourable member for Robertson himself when he held the portfolio responsibility. Having said that, may I say that this commemorative project has my full personal support and I have indicated to the shire that I will assist in any appropriate way with fund raising for the project, and I reiterate to the shire today that I personally will do whatever I can to help. As for that part of the honourable gentleman's question which suggests that I should have a talk with the Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the National Party, I am more than happy to do that. On the basis of the record so far, I would not think it would be terribly productive, but I am always ambitious in these matters and I will talk to them.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support. Did the Minister receive a card from motorist organisations with 2c attached? Is this part of the Australian Automobile Association's (AAA) political campaign against the Federal Government's road funding program and is there any substance in the Association's assertions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I did. I also understand from a newspaper report, from the National Roads and Motorists Association (NRMA) at least, that one of those cards was sent to each member of the House of Representatives-that is 148-and to 76 members of the Senate as well. I think that part of the campaign went down like a lead balloon, because only about two people have mentioned to me that they received it. It really has not had a great deal of impact.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the things that I would like to mention is that although the 2c attached to each of those cards really represents a relatively small amount of money, I suppose it does reflect the general contempt that the NRMA and the other State affiliates of the AAA have shown for the subscriptions of their members. Any honourable members who are members of those State motorist organisations need to keep in mind that part of the subscription is being used to fund a $6m campaign against the road funding programs of the Federal Government.

The honourable member for Throsby asks whether there was any basis to the claims of the AAA. It has made essentially two claims. The first is that the Hawke Government has reduced the level of funding for roads. It has done no such thing. In fact the Hawke Government, during its six years, has applied directly to the national roads system a greater volume of money in both nominal and real terms than has ever been applied by any government in any six-year period in the history of this Commonwealth. In fact the amount has increased by over 20 per cent in real terms and that represents an annual average increase of $250m every year for those six years. The second claim it has made is that only 20 per cent of the fuel excise goes back into the road system. I want to emphasise that that 20 per cent represents what the Federal Government injects back into the road system directly, that is, $1.2 billion. But, in addition, the State governments inject another $1.6 billion back into the road system, largely from the over $12 billion that the Federal Government makes available to them in untied grants. In addition to that, State governments put an extra $1.5 billion back into the road system. That represents $4.3 billion every year going back into the road system from three levels of government, and that represents 85 per cent of the fuel excise.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

The problem that this Government has with its aviation policy is that it is politically based. It is not based on logic. It is not based on the needs of the aviation or the tourist industry in Australia. It is based on the political needs of one very junior Minister. He holds the marginal seat of Barton by about one per cent and spent, I am told, about $160,000 or $170,000 at the last election to try to keep that seat--

TALK.START.PARA: —One hundred and eighty-five thousand dollars.

—The figure was $185,000, I am told. No matter what the Government does, he is doomed at the forthcoming election. There is widespread support for the construction of this third runway. The first comment I would like to make is that the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown), who is in the chamber, is on record as saying that he hopes the Government bites the bullet on this. I am pleased that the honourable member for Parramatta is in the chamber.
—He is nodding his head.

—He is nodding. I wonder what he thinks about Gary Punch being on the front bench and his sitting back there, and I wonder what he thinks about Gerry Hand on the front bench and him back there. But let us get back to the issue at hand of support for the third runway. Speaking on a Sydney radio program, John Brown said:

SPEECH.PARA: What hasn't been properly amplified to the public about the third runway is that the third runway is about departures only . . . As of now departures share the other runways with incoming flights.

It is simple logic to me that if you take the departures and put them all out over the Bay on a new runway it diminished the amount of traffic which is now driving the local residents mad, and good politics I would have thought.
I hope the government takes the bit in their teeth and builds the third runway.

Earlier today I asked the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support whether he would provide the advice that he had received from the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) on the consequences in terms of aircraft noise for people who live around the airport. Do not ask me how I know, but I know what advice the CAA has given to the Minister on this. I know the date he got it. In fact I may even be prepared to say that I have a copy of it. But he is not even prepared to make a comment on it. What is important is that he is not prepared to have a public discussion. In fact, the Minister and the Government at large are running what can only be described as a disinformation campaign on the construction of this vitally needed piece of social and economic infrastructure. One would think they were proposing to build a missile base or something. We are talking about an airport-a public works construction project. There should be public debate about it. But, no, the whole thing is being conducted in secret. The debate is political-not economic, not rational and not based on the needs of the industry or the needs of the community. There is a determination not to provide any information.

My colleague the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) has asked a series of questions of the Government about the construction of Badgerys Creek and, of course, on the third runway at Kingsford-Smith. I think some of these questions on notice go back a year. They are fairly straightforward and simple questions, but we still do not have answers. The reason we do not have answers is, firstly, that the Government does not know the answers, or, secondly, that it would be horribly embarrassed for its very junior Minister if the information became public. The whole situation has become a question of high farce.

Late last year, as a result of questions we put in this place, the junior Minister made comments about how the Government would accelerate the construction of Badgerys Creek. He said that a submission would go to Cabinet before Christmas. It is now March. When that did not happen he said that the submission would go to Cabinet in February. That did not happen. It went to Cabinet but was postponed and now I am told the Government is trying to organise another meeting for Thursday of this week when it will finally take a decision. Today we appreciate from the answers we got from the Minister for Administrative Services that the Government really does not know what it will do and its starting point is general aviation. We have to contrast that comment with the comments made by the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, who when he started to make his comments talked about a full international airport being constructed in five years. Then it went down to three years. The other week in this place he tabled letters from Lend Lease saying that it can build the airport in four years. He is not addressing the fact that the Government has not fulfilled the preconditions attached to the Lend Lease offer, and that is that it does not own the land. I will refer to some of the problems with acquiring land. It is interesting that the Government will use new legislation to acquire it on an accelerated program. That will be a very interesting proposition.

When it comes to addressing some of the more fundamental issues, the Government is determined to walk away from them. It amazes me that it is not prepared to adopt a more rational approach to this facility. Someone in the Government must have some sort of conscience, and I hope it is Senator Walsh, the Minister for Finance. Whilst the proposal for a third runway is quite feasible in construction and economic terms, the Government is not prepared to do it. It keeps talking about accelerating the construction of Badgerys Creek. If the Government is going to make the announcement on Badgerys Creek properly, not only does it have to tell us what sort of facility it will have and when it will complete all the necessary arrangements before construction begins, such as the acquisition of the land, the environmental impact studies and the review of the flight paths around the Sydney basin, but also it has to tell us how much more the facility will cost us not than just the third runway but because it is being accelerated in its construction. It should also tell us how much more it will cost because it delayed its decision on going ahead with this facility.

Before the Prime Minister abruptly ended Question Time, I was going to ask the Government a further question. I hope that the Minister for Transport and Communications, who is at the table, and who will obviously respond to this motion, has an answer for me. The Government's official reports say that Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport is currently operating at 200,000 movements a year. Two hundred and twenty thousand movements are anticipated by the end of 1990. The estimate by the Federal Airports Corporation is that the demand on Kingsford-Smith will reach 340,000 movements by the year 2000. That is not very far away. The Minister for Administrative Services has said that we can build a general aviation facility with some sort of international capacity. I wish he would be a bit more precise.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is unstated.

—Yes, unstated. I would like to know what the Government's estimates are of what sort of facility it needs to build to cope with the overflow and also to cope with the 100,000 movements that will be displaced from Hoxton Park when Badgerys Creek is open, because Hoxton Park is closed. How long will it take to construct that facility and what sort of air traffic control facilities will it apply to this new airport?

SPEECH.PARA: At present I believe the Government is running for cover. It has dug itself a monumental hole. In fact, the hole has been dug by the junior Minister, and every time he says something he digs it a bit deeper. As I said, that is why he is not here today. The Government is desperately working behind the scenes to come up with some sort of proposal that will have some sort of credibility not only in this Parliament but also in the community and in the aviation industry. The general view of the aviation industry is that the Government is suffering from policy paralysis. It puts the interests of one member ahead of the entire industry and the tourist industry. The great problem is that people actually make tape recordings of what goes on.

The problem is that the media is a bit like Parliament. It writes down what one says. Unless one is careful about what one says one has a monumental problem.

When it comes to Badgerys Creek it is not all plain sailing. It has massive problems. The largest dairy farm supplying milk to Sydney is located there. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the Overseas Telecommunications Commission have stations there. The list goes on. It will need 70,000 cubic metres of fill, and the environmental impact studies have not been completed. At the very beginning of my remarks I said that this Government has allowed itself to be pushed into a political position as a result of the right wing of the Labor Party not thinking carefully about who got what job and also the national consequences of some very parochial politics that go back to the days when a certain person was campaigning for local government. It has just snowballed into a situation where we now have the entire aviation industry in Australia being held to ransom because this Government did not think through its policy. It does not think through its policy in transport and aviation very carefully. I could list at length its problems with Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines, the Civil Aviation Authority, the Federal Airports Corporation, Perth Airport and a whole range of other issues. But the reality is that it does not have a policy position.

This Government needs to tell the Minister to be objective. If he is not prepared to be objective the Government should remove him. We should have a full public debate on what the airport needs of Sydney are. We should not have the determination to hide the information. We need to put it all on the table, take a rational decision and have an environmental impact study as proposed by the New South Wales Government. We should know what the costs of it are. We should then-and I am sure this is what we will end up doing-proceed to develop the third runway at Kingsford-Smith and also, on a rational cost effective timetable, develop a second airport for Sydney. We should not have this half-baked political response to a crisis that has arisen simply because one junior Minister cannot control his mouth and has pushed the Government to the limit of political credibility.

The Government has put an end to the two-airline policy. The decision to develop the second Sydney airport at Badgerys Creek was a very important one made by this Government. It followed a long environmental impact study involving 18 to 20 months-I think 20 months-of study before the decision was made as to where the airport should be.

Having made that decision, we have now moved on to the next stage of seeking to acquire the land. As the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) said during Question Time, we have acquired a little under half of the properties. Of course, the new Lands Acquisition Act, which is currently in the Senate, pays particular regard to the rights of individuals whose land is being acquired. From their point of view, it is a much better piece of legislation than that which currently prevails. But, of course, at present we are not pursuing a compulsory land acquisition process; we are doing it by way of voluntary purchase.

Therefore, we are well on the way to the establishment of the second Sydney airport. If the Government decides that we should accelerate that program, that can be done. The land can be acquired more quickly and we can move quickly into the development of that second Sydney airport. The question is: should that be done now or later? I am not going to canvass those arguments here. Those are arguments for consideration in Cabinet. Once Cabinet has made its decision we will be only too willing to tell this Parliament and the nation why we made that decision.

I think it is relevant to note that much of the controversy which has been occurring-probably much more outside the Parliament than inside it-in relation to whether there should be an immediate move to develop a second Sydney airport or to further develop the Kingsford-Smith Airport by use of a third runway has proceeded on a massive amount of misinformation. All sorts of people who have a vested interest in this issue one way or the other have been putting in their oars and saying things which are without real justification. In particular, one point I would like to draw attention to is the allegation by many people that there is a quick-fire solution to the need for more runway space in the Sydney region, and that is to build a third runway. The fact of life simply is that that is not a quick solution. There should be no misunderstanding about that at all. Whatever else one wants to say about it, it is not a quick solution because there would need to be an environmental impact statement. We have had an environmental impact statement for Badgerys Creek which was very comprehensive. Any further environmental impact statement that needed to be done would be a much smaller exercise than the one that was undertaken before.

In relation to the third runway, there would need to be a comprehensive environmental impact statement where no such study has been done. That would certainly take quite a period of time, after which the runway would need to be constructed, which cannot be done until there is a lot of filling in of the sea. That process would be very time consuming indeed. I am not going to go into our understanding of these time schedules now, but let me say quite emphatically that, in our considered view, looking at all of the evidence we now have available to us, there is no doubt whatever that in the time frame that it takes to build a third runway we could have a quite substantial second Sydney airport at Badgerys Creek.

The lead time to construct that runway is an estimated seven years. The lead time for a second airport is 10 to 12 years.

On 26 March 1987, during the debate on private investment in airport terminals, when we were talking about the development of a third runway or a second international airport for Sydney, that speaker said that either the runway or the new international airport `would take in the order of eight to 10 years to build, presuming of course that a second runway could be built into Botany Bay'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—The speaker on those occasions was the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, who comes in here now and tells us that he is going to build a brand new airport at Badgerys Creek in three or four years. The real facts are these: it is absolutely impossible to get a fully operating brand new international airport under way at Badgerys Creek in less than 10 years. If the Government wants to do it in 10 years it will have to fast track the project. If it fast tracks the project, it will have the same situation as it had with the new Parliament House-there is going to be a doubling of the cost. Ten years' time is the earliest that we could possibly get a brand new international airport running in Sydney. The fact is that it would take three to five years to get a third runway operating at Kingsford-Smith Airport. SPEECH.PARA: Another fact which the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis), referred to is that the navigational equipment and the safety aids operating out of Sydney are decades old. I think it has been a matter of gross neglect that they have not been upgraded over the years. Sydney operates on aircraft separations of three minutes. In a parallel runway situation in places such as Chicago and Los Angeles, aircraft separations are 20 seconds. I am not suggesting that Australia need go to a stage where we have 20-second separations, but there is a very great difference between a separation of 20 seconds and a separation of three minutes.

The facts are that we are understaffed with air traffic controllers and the new air traffic controllers we are getting in at the moment have not had the training to handle the heavy traffic; we have antiquated equipment; and we have absolutely no indication, apart from what the Minister just mumbled, of what we are going to do to update that equipment. But do we hear anything from the Government about putting a little vision into the situation at Kingsford-Smith Airport? The Australian of 15 February of this year reported:
Precision-landing techniques being tried in the United States could double the capacity of Sydney airport, if a small, additional runway were built.
This would invalidate the Federal Government's claim that a proposed close-spaced runway at Sydney would increase capacity by only about 40 per cent.

In fact, if we worked closely with the Federal aviation authorities in the United States we would see that we could double the capacity of Sydney international airport in a few years with that extra runway. One would then wonder, in light of what is happening with aircraft development, whether we would need that second airport at all.

The honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), who spoke earlier, indicated that the cost of building Badgerys Creek on a planned basis is about $1 billion in today's terms. But we could get that into place and get it operating in three to five years and save a lot of money. We could then invest in the futuristic air traffic control mechanisms that are being developed and use them within a matter of years. But no, we have to go through the charade that is being put on, and has been put on by this Government for some years now, as to what the real situation is concerning Kingsford-Smith Airport. The situation is that there are 16,000 people, many of whom live in the electorate of Barton, working at the airport. I suppose they will all be very thrilled about packing a cut lunch and a thermos of Milo to take out to Badgerys Creek when they go to work, because that is what will happen. Within the immediate area of Kingsford-Smith Airport an additional 60,000 jobs are being provided from offshoots to the requirements of that airport. International airlines are presently looking at other destinations to avoid the bottleneck at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith). Let the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch) go back to his electorate and confess that he is depriving the people of Sydney of jobs for their kids. That is what he is doing. Every time the number of international visitors to Australia increases by a net 1,400, that means an additional job for a young Australian. The cartoon in this morning's Canberra Times was right. The real hidden agenda, of course, is that the Opposition wants a wide space parallel runway. It does not mention that when it campaigns in Barton or St George or in any of the seats surrounding the airport. There has been no discussion about the impact of a new runway on Botany Bay National Park and the mangroves in Towra Point. It has no concern for the people who live near Mascot Airport. SPEECH.PARA: (1) That, in accordance with the terms of the resolution of the House of Representatives of 8 May 1985 and of the Senate of 10 May 1985, the reference of the acquisition of automatic data processing facilities by any Commonwealth Department or authority to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts be rescinded; and
(2) That a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of this resolution.

On 8 May 1985 this House resolved to refer to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts proposed acquisitions of automatic data processing (ADP) facilities by Commonwealth departments or authorities. The House also resolved that the resolution continue in force unless and until amended or rescinded by the House or the Senate. The Senate concurred with the resolution on 10 May 1985. The old procedures for ADP acquisitions provided for compulsory referral to the Committee of acquisitions costing more than $5m. In March 1988 the Government agreed to new procedures which no longer included compulsory referral of proposals to the Committee but still enabled Ministers to refer any particular proposal to the Committee.

The new procedures contain the following elements: departments and authorities are required to prepare an information technology strategic plan every three years. The plan is to identify a strategy for the development, use and management of information technology and to show how the technology will contribute to the goals and objectives of the organisation. Acquisitions that cost less than $5m and are consistent with the information technology plan can proceed subject to receiving approval in the Budget process. Proposals for acquisition costing $5m or more are to be considered by Cabinet for in principle approval outside the Budget process and funding approval as part of the Budget process. A department or authority must establish an acquisitions council to provide an independent source of advice where an acquisition proposal is likely to require Cabinet approval. The acquisitions council is to include at least one member of standing from outside the organisation and at least one member from a central agency. The council provides an independent report on the proposed acquisition, which is attached to the Cabinet submission. The departments and their authorities should refer in their annual reports to information technology acquisition approvals in excess of $5m, including information on goals and priorities. The Department of Administrative Services in responsible for providing tendering and contracting services and for ensuring that propriety and probity are observed in procurement action.

The decision to remove compulsory referral to the Committee was taken after an efficiency scrutiny review which identified shortcomings in the old procedures. The review concluded that, in the case of computer acquisitions, a review by the Public Accounts Committee is of limited benefit, is costly and introduces significant delay.

Accordingly, this motion rescinds the resolution of 8 May 1985 but it does so in the context of both that deliberation by the efficiency scrutiny which found that this was no longer required and was costly, and also the fact that now a considerable process of oversight has been put in place to deal with these problems within the departments-an oversight that was not in place back in 1985.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that the report proposed in this amendment will eliminate some of those doubts. There is some question as to the viability of projects on several grounds. We see examples reported of the effects of projects financed and undertaken by the World Bank and its affiliates, including the IBRD, which have effects on indigenous people to which one would think, given the rhetoric of this Government, we would not as a country want to be a party or give the stamp of our imprimatur.

It is therefore an important responsibility for us to do what we can to assess what the bank is doing and to ensure that it operates efficiently and along the lines of its charter. My colleague has raised some serious questions in that regard.

At the time we debated this matter I said that we ought to be looking at more cost effective ways of giving assistance to developing countries, and that there should be a greater involvement of the private sector and, particularly, non-government organisations. I mentioned at that point an organisation with which I am associated, the Maranatha Trust of Sydney, which has programs in many parts of the world, but I refer particularly to the Philippines. It is attempting to stimulate a bit of grass roots capitalism in that country. Advances of money are made to people in the so-called informal sector, the poorest of the poor, who have no collateral to put up in order to borrow funds and establish small businesses. The Maranatha Trust makes such advances without collateral and achieves very effective results in terms of increased employment, greater self-esteem and great assistance to large numbers of the poor in that country. The overseas aid cost from this country can average out to $100 per job, whereas I know of jobs `created' by the World Bank which cost in the order of $500,000 a job.

TALK.START.PARA: —Big overheads-a 6,000 strong staff.

—Let alone the 6,000 strong bureaucracy that my colleague has mentioned. That is a tremendous contrast. TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Housing and Aged Care)

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened carefully to this debate. I have not been able to be present in the chamber all the time, but certainly I have kept my eyes and ears on it, as have many of my staff. I generally commend honourable members for their contributions and interest in what is a very important area of policy and action in our community.

SPEECH.PARA: On listening to some of the contributions made by those on the other side of the chamber I wondered whether they fully understood the implications of the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Amendment Bill. While recognising that it was a very wide-ranging debate and that many honourable members had many local or general issues to raise, I feel that in many cases the point of the Bill was lost. It goes to the heart of the matter in that, instead of having the old system of ad hoc arrangements and a lack of planning, we are in this Bill, along with others that have gone before it, bringing in some very important policies and positions to deal with the issues concerning aged care in this country.

I refer honourable members to the explanatory memorandum to the Bill. I draw their attention and the public's attention to the fact that this Bill deals with planning arrangements. Planning was almost totally lacking in aged care in this country until this Government decided to grasp the bull by the horns and do something about it. In view of the issues that were facing Australia because of the ageing of the population there was a need to make sure that the resources were used properly in government and within the community in general.

This Bill introduces new hostel planning arrangements which determine the maximum number of hostel places to be funded on a recurrent basis for each State and Territory at any time in a particular financial year. It enables the Minister to specify the distribution of those hostel places among planning regions. In the first part of the Bill we have the whole concept for planning and putting the hostel places where they are actually needed. The Bill also introduces an approval in principle arrangement for the provision of capital and recurrent funding or recurrent funding alone in respect of the acquisition, erection, demolition, reconstruction, alteration, extension or transfer of a hostel. That in itself is another planning procedure that provides organisations and people who are keen to provide much needed hostels in Australia with a process by which they can plan for a development and be sure of subsequent approval-in most cases-if they fulfil the general requirements of the legislation.

The Bill also enables us to ensure that all Commonwealth funded hostels-existing and future-are approved for a fixed number of hostel places, including, importantly, respite care, for recurrent funding purposes. That allows us again to improve the financial management and planning in the hostel sector. The Bill ensures that the approved number of hostel places will be occupied only by eligible persons. It is a waste, totally unnecessary and not necessarily appropriate for the people themselves if the occupants of a hostel are not eligible persons. Obviously a hostel is there for a purpose. The Government-the taxpayers-pays a considerable subsidy towards the upkeep and operation of it. It should be there for people who need it; not simply as a form of alternative accommodation for those who are not in a state of frailty.

Very importantly, the Bill enables the payment of a recurrent subsidy for an eligible person occupying an approved respite care place for a maximum of 63 days in a benefit period in the same hostel. That is a considerable advantage to hostel operators. It certainly removes many of the inadequacies or unnecessary paperwork and confusion that arose in the past. The Bill enables money borrowed or received from the Commonwealth or borrowed from other sources to be taken into account in calculating the amount of a capital grant in relation to a nursing home. That is an added plus when it comes to the development of our aged care sector. It also brings in another range of transitional arrangements.

I make the point at the outset that rarely in the debate were those sorts of points brought home. As honourable members have been quite willing to point out, many changes are occurring. We are bringing about a very important planning, consultation and development emphasis to the whole of the aged care sector. Opposition members did not refer to the importance of those points, which I think are extremely relevant to the development of aged care in Australia; they simply referred to problems they felt existed in the aged care area in general. Unfortunately, many of them not only were misinformed on some points but also made quite spurious claims and in some cases-I would hesitate to say this but I suspect it is truly the case-deliberately misrepresented the successful programs that this Government has introduced.

I am unable to understand how the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), in talking about the bed ratio, said that nursing bed availability will be reduced from the present figure of about 70,000 beds to about 45,000 beds by the time the program is completed. That is in complete contradiction to any of the released figures and any of the understandings of the industry of which I am aware, given the fact that there will be an increase in the number of nursing home beds, particularly over the next three years, of about 1,400. While we have over 75,000 nursing home beds at the moment, the implication-I hope it is not the case but I can only draw this implication from his words-is that about 25,000 beds will be taken out of the nursing home program.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were 1,500 taken out in the previous 12 months.

—That is not the case. There has been an extension of the nursing home program. That is indicated by the growth that is projected over the next three years alone. If the honourable member for Dawson wants to show me his figures or the sources he got them from, I will be quite happy to explore them. Perhaps I have misunderstood what he was talking about. However, they were in contradiction of what is actually being done. There will be a steady increase in the number of nursing home beds while at the same time-and it is very relevant to this Bill-there will be a huge increase in hostel beds. When this Government came in there were only about 22,000 hostel beds in Australia. By 1990, after only seven years in government, we will have effectively doubled that number to about 43,000. That brings an element of flexibility into the aged care system that just was not there before. It brings in options that were not there before. That is something members of the Opposition are quite happy to accept when hostels are opened in their electorates and their constituents get the benefit, but it seems that when they come into this place they throw around figures to denigrate the massive program of capital works and recurrent expenditure that this Government has undertaken to fulfil the need that exists in our community to plan for the future in a way that was not done under the previous Government.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government's priority of fair and equitable planning is encompassed in this Bill and has certainly replaced the ad hoc arrangements of the past. The reform strategy is underpinned by several basic requirements. The first is that aged people should be supported as long as they wish to be, in particular in their own homes, by residential services as long as this best suits their needs. There must also be promotion of rehabilitation, thereby enhancing personal freedom and independence, and a recognition that a move to a less supported residential or community based support centre will be possible and desirable for some people.

It is therefore of concern when honourable members opposite, and some in particular, criticise the Government for the home and community care (HACC) program. The honourable member for Lowe (Dr Woods) mentioned that the Government had `cut the guts'-I think they were the words he used-out of the home and community care program. That is quite amazing considering that, when this Government came to office in 1983, the total combined expenditure of the Commonwealth on programs that now come under the HACC umbrella was about $53m. At this stage this year the Government is spending about $210m. That is the Commonwealth's contribution-$210m this year. If that is cutting the guts out of a program that is seeking not only to extend the traditional home care services but to add new services tailored to individual needs, then certainly I am quite happy to have that accusation levelled at this Government and at me on any occasion.

One of the other issues that have been raised relates to the figure of 87 1/2 per cent. In July 1991, due to the funding arrangements this Government has been putting into place, no person living in a fully government sponsored nursing home-and that will represent about 94 per cent of beds-will be required to pay more than 87 1/2 per cent of the standard pension rate, plus rent assistance. That is is in direct contrast to the situation that exists for so many thousands of people today, where many have to pay not only that standard pension contribution but fees of the order of thousands and thousands of dollars a year. Yet it would seem that that is what the Opposition is pushing for.

This Government is bringing in a system of aged care support in this country as security for older people at the point of greatest vulnerability in terms of their financial security as well as their health security. This Government has set about a program, as part of its overall reform strategy, of ensuring that no one need pay more than 87 1/2 per cent of the standard pension rate plus rent assistance for living in a nursing home. But the Opposition-as has been stated in its policy, espoused by the New South Wales Council of the Liberal Party and by members in this House-is now setting out on a new path. The Opposition's approach would ensure that old people who deserve that security, that time in their lives when they do not have to worry about having to rely upon their own resources or upon the support of friends or relatives, are returned to insecurity.

The honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Pratt) made a number of comments about lack of consultation. If consultation has occurred on any issue in Australia over the last couple of years, I think it has been in the whole area of aged care, whether it be the nursing home industry, hostels or home and community care. There has not been a lack of consultation but, in many cases, overconsultation. There have been some quite significant changes of direction, but certainly all along the way every attempt has been made at consultation.

The honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks)-and I thank him for it-was appreciative of the efforts that had gone into ensuring that under the new arrangements, as he has been assured and the Cobar Council has been assured, the Lilliane Brady Nursing Home in the remote town of Cobar will not suffer under the small home arrangements. I think that is very important. A lot of other comments were made in the House about this issue as a way of scaring people, particularly those in the more remote areas, into believing that their very important nursing home accommodation would be taken away or else be made not viable. That is certainly not the case. Anyone who knows the location, the remoteness and the size of Cobar would imagine that if any town were to suffer then that town probably would, because of its locality, but that is not the case-and the honourable member for Riverina-Darling, to his credit, has acknowledged that.

Other members have spoken about the issue. The honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) also raised the point. I think we have to recognise-and I hope it is now recognised in the community-that there are a number of small nursing homes in Australia, whether they be in urban areas or in remote areas, which we want to encourage, particularly in remote areas, to continue to serve their communities in the ways they have. We are therefore looking at ways not only of improving their viability but also of enhancing the quality of care they can give. Services such as a 24-hour director of nursing cover did not exist before but exist now. Many of the small homes will receive quite significant increases in nursing home hours as a result of the changes we have brought in, as well as the consultancy support that will help them to rationalise and improve their structures and efficiencies. If members of the Opposition are concerned about any small homes in their electorates, I would certainly welcome their representations and we will look at them on an individual basis. The Department is similarly setting out to assist those homes. I can assure people in remote areas of Australia that their aged care services will not suffer; in fact, they will be enhanced.

The honourable member for Lowe, in one of his typical speeches, talked a lot about dreaded socialism and inappropriately putting people into hostels when many were too frail to be there. I appreciate that the honourable member is a doctor but perhaps he has not spent much time speaking recently to people in nursing homes about the way in which the consultancy was carried out. He will find that many people who are in nursing homes at the moment, if they had the opportunity again, would choose to be in hostel care.

We certainly recognise that people in hostels will need to have more care. That is why we have set in place, as hostel operators know, a process of increasing the personal care subsidy. We do not consider hostels to be simply a cheaper option. They are for people who do not need to be in nursing homes, where so many people in the past were placed inappropriately. We consider them to be a better option in terms of quality of life and, in many cases, quality of care for certain individuals. Quality of life is very important to this Government in the way in which it respects the older people in our community.

The honourable member for Lowe also said that there would be no funding for new nursing homes. That is just patently wrong. If he has any issues that he wants to raise-and I would like some of the honourable members opposite to show me their figures to back up the assertions that they have been making throughout this debate-then I would be quite happy to consider them and give them a full and open response in the hope that honourable members would be better informed in debates in future. Many honourable members spoke about a lack of information. If any honourable members opposite want any information, they can have a box load of it delivered to their office. On the other hand, the Opposition claims in the same debate, when it talks about a lack of information about what has been happening, that a whole lot of government propaganda has been put out. So it is a little difficult to understand what it really wants when it is all boiled down.

The honourable member for Lowe and others have made reference to financially disadvantaged people. I am quite amazed at this. There is a problem in this country in that many of the hostels and nursing homes have an attitude-and it was expressed to me at a seminar that I was addressing earlier this morning-that hostel operators should only take who they want to take and that the Government should be responsible for the financially disadvantaged. That is lovely, is it not? We have a situation here where nearly all these hostel operators in the past, or possibly in the future, have been receiving substantial Commonwealth subsidies in terms of capital and certainly receiving substantial subsidies in terms of personal care, yet they are ready to flick off the financially disadvantaged as the ordinary pensioner's, the ordinary person's, battle.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not saying all of them do?
—No, I am not saying that all of them do, but some do.
—Make it clear.

—I will come back to the point you are raising shortly. They are ready to flick these people off into some other hostel. (Extension of time granted) The honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) addressed the need for information and consultation. I notice that he also mentioned that he had not been to any of the seminars in his area, although he had been told that nursing homes needed more information. What nursing homes, the people who operate them and their boards of management-the people who work in them-need is in fact not more information on paper but the ability to discuss and get to grips with the changes that are going on. When one considers that there are about 1,400 nursing homes throughout Australia and the best part of 1,000 hostels, and when one then adds up the number of people on boards of management, mostly in a voluntary capacity, it is obviously very difficult to understand the vast changes that are going on. I can assure those opposite that the Government is doing all it can to foster the development of that information and understanding. Again, if honourable members opposite have any ideas as to ways in which that can be enhanced, then I am only too happy to look at it.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) was a little bit confused on one point that he raised. He spoke about nursing homes in remote areas. He was concerned about small homes. He said that they are only going to get $4,000 a bed and asked how any bed could be built for $4,000. I point out to the honourable member for Barker that this Government does not expect any nursing home, or hostel operator for that matter, to provide a bed for $4,000 of capital. What is important to realise, considering the way in which the Opposition has attacked this Government's relationship with the age care sector, is that that $4,000 is not simply a capital subsidy for them to go out and build a new bed. For the first time, that subsidy is not just a capital subsidy but an interest subsidy to help private nursing home operators in restructuring. It is actually an extra grant for money that has already been put forward by the private nursing home operators to help them overcome the subsidy arrangement. So here we have a situation of extra support for the first time being given to the private sector. In fact, for an ordinary bed, the rate is about $23,000. For a financially disadvantaged bed, if a hostel decides to set up a percentage, as hostels are supposed to for financially disadvantaged, the rate is $46,400 plus the land subsidy per bed. Again, if the Opposition wants to get more information, then I am quite happy to provide it.

A lot was said about user rights and Chris Ronalds's report entitled I'm Still an Individual. That report is a very important one. It forms the basis of stage 5 of the Government's eight-stage program of aged care reform that will go through to 1992. This is to do with residents' rights now, and this is the major push this year, considering that most of the funding arrangements and the planning and organisational arrangements have been dealt with in the past. Chris Ronalds is a respected lawyer. She has done a lot of work in this area. It is not only her work, but what perhaps honourable members opposite do not know or, if they do know, fail to recognise, is that this consultancy did not simply involve her running around Australia talking to a lot of people. It was under a steering committee led and chaired quite ably-and I thank him very much-by Professor Peter Hanks of Monash University. There were consumers on that committee from the Australian Council on the Ageing, the Australian Pensioners Federation, the Accommodation Rights Service, the Older Persons Action Centre, the Pensioners Action Group and the Aged Care Coalition. Perhaps the Opposition would like to level some of its accusations about user rights at those groups instead of directing them simply and solely at Chris Ronalds. Perhaps they would also like to accuse the unions of bashing away at nursing home proprietors because the Royal Australian Nursing Federation, or as it is now the Australian Nurses Federation, and the Queensland Nurses Union were also represented. Apart from the Commonwealth Department, Senator Giles and the Western Australian Bureau of the Aged, there were also representatives of providers-John Gilroy from the Australian Nursing Homes Association and Donald Coburn of the Australian Affiliation of Voluntary Care Associations (AAVCA). Considering the comments that have come particularly from Mr Gilroy as well as the AAVCA, I believe that they are very supportive of the general direction the Government is taking in aged care and the Government's initiatives to ensure that people in nursing homes and hostels throughout Australia have the best quality of life, and in relation to their dignity and self-respect, that we as a society and they as providers and the staff can provide for them. I commend them for that.

It is disappointing that there has been such a reaction from honourable members in this House and particularly from people in Victoria. I was hoping, as were Chris Ronalds and the rest of the steering committee-and everything that I have been saying has been to this end-that the issue of user rights in residential care and for older people generally is very much a community issue. Those of us who have good health, who do not depend on other people and who have good jobs do not realise the problems that affect us down the track when we are older, perhaps when we are more frail and vulnerable and when we need to depend on others for care. What people were saying to Chris Ronalds, as well as on the hot line that has run in different States, concerned not so much the issues surrounding their fees or water being in the orange juice but simple human issues of dignity and respect which need to be addressed in their day to day lives. Sometimes in our community we do not pay sufficient regard to how people feel. I believe that this is a valuable report because it points the way, without attributing blame to anyone.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!
—That is not the case-and if the honourable member has read the report and listened to what I have said and to what other people have said--
—It is ideologically bent.

—The only ideologically bent thing in this House is the honourable member for Gippsland. What we are trying to do is to encourage in the community some understanding of the issues and the way in which older people feel.
—You have slurred a whole lot of dedicated people.
—I have not slurred anyone. I would hope that the community will look at this issue and look at the report. I would hope that the nursing home industry will look at it--
—They have, and they have rejected it.

—We will see whether they have rejected it. I would hope that they will look at the report and look at ways in which they can improve the situation-just simply assess and look at those very important issues. Despite the calls of some honourable members opposite, I believe out in the community there is genuine understanding. There could be some people who feel a bit defensive or that their effort has not been considered properly. I can assure the House that this Government certainly appreciates the tremendous work that is done, often in very difficult circumstances, by all those in the nursing home industry. There is always room for improvement of the community's attitudes to the needs of the aged and the way in which we treat them as individuals.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to talk specifically, in the minute I have left, about the issue that the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) and others have raised; that is, for existing hostels, the problems associated with the Government's requirement that 20 per cent of the total number of permanent places be for financially disadvantaged people. It has been a requirement of the recurrent funding agreement at least since 1984 that hostels provide that level of access for financially disadvantaged people. However, it has been recognised that some organisations may not immediately be able to attain that 20 per cent minimum requirement of places for financially disadvantaged persons in each of their existing hostels. Representatives of the Uniting Church in New South Wales approached the Government-despite the fact that we have been talking about it for quite a while-when it came down to the wire, to see whether, across their 35 hostels, there was any way in which the Government could address this matter. We have had discussions with them. I thought that the situation had been resolved. Maybe it has not been. But this Government has made a considerable concession to that organisation and others like it to aggregate that requirement across their facilities and I hope that that will satisfy the honourable member.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 23, after clause 20, insert the following new clause:
Certain provisions not to apply to an organisation which has not received any subsidy towards capital cost of an approved hostel
``20a. Before section 10fb of the Principal Act, the following section is inserted:
Provisions not to apply in certain circumstances

`10fab. Nothing in section 10f or 10fa of this Act or in the General Conditions formulated by the Minister under section 10f of this Act shall require an organisation which has not received a subsidy towards the capital cost of an approved hostel to enter into an agreement to admit, or to admit, any person who would be defined as a financially disadvantaged person.'.''.

In speaking to the amendment, particularly to the point in question without relating to the rest of the Bill, I found it extremely difficult when confronted with the current legislation to find the precedent for the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) to be doing various things that seemed to be in conflict with the legislation we were yet to consider. Apparently it goes back to earlier legislation of 1987, the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act, by which certain amendments were made to the Act which gave the Minister fairly wide discretion in administering general provisions within the Act. One of the aspects of the 1987 amendments was the introduction under clause 10f of general conditions of recurrent grants. One then goes to following subsections which allow the Minister to introduce these provisions. At the time, the Opposition agreed with those general provisions because they seemed to be in keeping with what the Opposition had in mind by way of reforms for the aged and frail aged. The amendment gave the Minister wide powers-one might say discretionary powers-and very little accountability at the end. Among other provisions, section 10f (2) (c) reads:
the class or classes of persons to be accommodated at an approved hostel and, where there are to be two or more classes, the proportion of the residents at the hostel included in each class.

As I understand it, even at that time there was a category of financially disadvantaged persons. I am not sure about the background of the second reading speech at that time, as to what the Government intended, but certainly since 1987 and the passing of that Act, what the Government had in mind has become much clearer. In the second reading debate, or the summary, we discussed paragraph (d), the fees or charges payable by a person or class of persons and, contrary to what the Minister says, the Opposition still does not disagree with that ceiling for those financially disadvantaged persons. We have never had that, but it surprises us that there is an allowance in the hostels legislation for a further contribution to be made to the capital cost, which then can be drawn down in relation to administration fees, but there is no such provision under the Nursing Homes Act where the ceiling is put at 87.5 per cent and I understand the extent of the housing subsidy beyond that.

We do not disagree with that, contrary to what the Minister has said, but we wonder why, where a person has an ability to pay fees as a consequence of having substantial property and having a need for nursing home care, a nursing home in certain cases cannot cross-subsidise against the cost of the financially disadvantaged, as we do in many other Commonwealth services. Telecom would be a good example of that, of which you, Mr Chairman, would be well aware.

We have also talked about paragraph (f) subsection (2) of section 10f-the rights and obligations of residents at an approved hostel. Again, I would say that that was put in there, and allowed to be put in by the Opposition of the day, without knowing the ramifications of it. In spite of what has been said about I'm Still an Individual, I go on record as saying that if one wanted a person to give a predictable answer, one would get a predictable person to provide that result. I am not saying that the author was not capable of doing the job. We are saying that it should have had a balance. I disagree with the Minister when he says that the committee that was responsible in that regard provided that balance. It did not. I have spoken to some of the members of that committee. While they were able to ameliorate some of the original suggestions, what came up eventually was not a fair reflection of the views of some of the members who sat on that committee.

There are a lot of other paragraphs of the subsection, going right up to (n). As I said, the Minister had a lot of discretion under those general conditions. We found just prior to Christmas, even though some of these things were discussed in consultation with the industry beforehand, that although the provisions of the regulations pertaining to the Statutory Rules Publication Act had been circumvented-except in some cases-that discretion means that the Minister can make general provisions providing they are not inconsistent with the general tone of the industry. He is allowed to gazette those for a period of 28 days and then have them declared as being the rules by which the game is played. According to letters which I have received, the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette refers to a tremendous amount of regulation and there was not time, from the time of presenting that regulation and its declaration, for proper consultation to have taken place.

We are particularly looking at one aspect of this, and that is under what policy or regulation-again this is basically under the hand of the Minister-a particular type of hostel is declared to be in a most disadvantaged area. I understand about 24 out of 950 hostels were encouraged to self-fund their capital funds. The Government of the day apparently went out and said, `If you capital fund these from your own resources, we will then provide the subsidies', and that has continued. Some of those hostels, because of group situations, have been able to aggregate their financially disadvantaged places and then spread them around. But in some cases those funds were raised on the basis of contractual arrangements with each of the residents. As far as I know those arrangements were paramount in law. The hostel owners, because of a contribution which would eventually be repaid at face value, would be allowed accommodation within those units.

The Government has said in those cases that the financially disadvantaged quota of residents has to stand at 20 per cent. The hostels were told, early in December I believe, that they had to complete an agreement by 10 January. They were under threat; one might even call it blackmail: `You either sign this or do without your subsidies'. What does a hostel that has a contractual arrangement do with its current arrangements when it has to sign an agreement which has built into it a 20 per cent quota for financially disadvantaged persons? I understand it was the industry that sought aggregation on certain terms, it was not something that was offered by the Minister. Under those terms the Minister was asked for a face to face discussion on the matter. He responded with a letter in which he laid down three conditions under which aggregation would take place. Under aggregation, this might have meant that the people would have to go from one region to another, and the organisations could not give a guarantee that aggregation would work under those terms because they had to find out from experience whether it would work. I do know that particular arrangement has caused deep distress in some cases, not for those hostels in the private sector, because the private sector hostels are not allowed to be subsidised, but for a genuine sector of the industry that has a proud record in this country of providing accommodation for the frail aged both in hostels and in nursing homes.

Our amendment seeks simply to exempt from the area of financially disadvantaged placements those hostels that have been fully self-funded, and particularly in this area of residential contracts. We see no financial disadvantage in this to the Government. It is not going to mean more financing. It is just going to mean that its philosophy of a 20 per cent quota for the disadvantaged cannot in these cases be fulfilled. I understand that these people can be taken into other homes under the arrangements providing for the placement of financially disadvantaged people.
