SPEECH.PARA: The point I want to make during the time that is available to me, and I do so for reasons of emphasis, is that it seems to me that the Government's policy since coming to office has been to seek to find places for financially disadvantaged people in resident funded hostels. That was a policy initiative of this Government's that presumably commenced early during its term of office, in 1984, and that may well be the case. But as most of these hostels were developed before then, I make the point that we are seeking retrospectively to change the arrangements under which certain churches, and they are mainly churches, were involved in building hostels with funds obtained either from the church, very often borrowed, or capital obtained from people who bought places in these hostels and people who I describe as the near poor, because they used up a great bulk of their own resources to get into a resident funded hostel. The Government has seen fit to alter the arrangements that were made with previous governments, whereby these arrangements were put in place.

These voluntary organisations essentially obtained funds, as I have mentioned, under this system so that the Government would provide additional hostel capacity with no capital funding by government involved. In other words, it was to save the Government of the day having to find the capital to build the hostels to meet the demand of people who required a level of personal care which they could not provide for themselves in their own homes, where meals and some servicing would be available but not the sort of greater attention that is required in a nursing home when people are less able to look after themselves. There was an agreement-that is how the hostels saw it-between the Government of the day and them which they believed would be honoured and continue to be honoured by successive governments. There was an expectation that the recurrent funding would be made by successive governments, because the Government of the day had agreed to raise this capital money. The difference was that in relation to the other hostels, the Government was meeting both the capital and the recurrent costs. Those hostels were financially geared on the basis that they would often borrow the money and over time, with the way in which fees were paid, some of the capital would be recouped. There was a form in which resident funded hostels were developed with interest free loans financed by residents to meet the total cost of the project. Traditionally those ongoing subsidies enabled the hostels to keep weekly fees below the age pension rate, and that was an important factor in the financial way in which these hostels were developed.

It is unconscionable for the Government to seek to rewrite an agreement retrospectively. It may be argued, technically, that the Government is now making it a condition of future recurrent funding that certain financially disadvantaged people be taken into these resident funded hostels. Although that may be a technical argument against retrospectivity, the impact of what is being proposed is certainly retrospective.

I would like the Minister to clarify for me whether he has discussed these matters, particularly, with the Uniting Church. I am not a member of the Uniting Church. I do not hold any particular brief for the Uniting Church in raising these matters. One of these resident funded hostels is in my electorate. I understand that it has been established for sufficient time so that this measure will not create a difficulty for it. The fact is that the impact of this legislation will vary greatly, having regard to whether a hostel was developed recently or is older. This is one of the points that needs to be clarified. I understand that officers of the Uniting Church have sought to see the Minister to put to him their concerns in a far more comprehensive and detailed way than I am able, particularly in relation to financing matters. They have not been able to see him in relation to these concerns. The Minister has said that the Government is keen to consult, sometimes there is too much consultation. I hope he is not saying, in relation to the Uniting Church's requests to see him, that there has been too much consultation.

I hope also that the Minister will be quite precise as to which of these resident funded hostels is not willing to accommodate any disadvantaged people. I understand that the Uniting Church in particular has sought to take such people. Originally, the church saw it as part of its mission to take in financially disadvantaged people. It was to assist the near poor, as I have said. If the Minister has in mind particular organisations that have been involved in resident funding which do not see it as their lot to assist financially disadvantaged persons, let us have it out in the open: which organisations are saying this? The Uniting Church assures me that it is not in that group. It tells me that certain of its newer hostels are so financially geared that it would provide problems for them to take in financially disadvantaged people at this point whereas that is not the case among the older hostels.

The question of aggregation arose in that area. I understand that the Minister has said that aggregation would be possible, that is, that the Uniting Church would be able to bring together all its hostels. Some of these hostels accommodate more financially disadvantaged people than the 20 per cent figure. The church wants to be able to say, `If our hostel at Ryde has a 40 per cent figure, the extra 20 per cent can go to, say, the Garrison at Mosman and be used to make up part of the 20 per cent financially disadvantaged component at that hostel'. That is what aggregation should mean, and that is what that organisation understood it to mean. I gather, from discussions with officers-maybe they do not understand what the Minister had in mind; I would like this to be clarified-that each hostel must have this 20 per cent component and that aggregation will be largely ineffective. This is of real concern to the Uniting Church. Its requirements could well have been met if aggregation were to be pursued in a realistic fashion. I understand from the way in which officers have proposed to rewrite the rules that the aggregation that was thought to be available under the Minister's written advice is, according to their understanding, not to be the case. That matter should be clarified today. It may well be that some of those concerns can be resolved. It does not in any way derogate from my principled concern that we ought not to rewrite these arrangements retrospectively, notwithstanding the Uniting Church's good intentions to provide accommodation for disadvantaged people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I recognise that you are very familiar with many of the issues that we are dealing with because of your chairmanship of the former House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure. The House and the country owe you and your Committee a great deal of gratitude for the work you achieved in developing a substantial increase in aged care reforms in this country. I make that point by way of introduction because this is a very complex area. In fact, the amendment that has been moved by the Opposition does not have very much to do with the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Amendment Bill. I suggest that the amendment relates more to the provisions of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1987. The Act was proclaimed and commenced operation on 11 January 1989. Prior to that time, the details of the new equitable funding arrangements for hostels had been the subject of very extensive consultation with service providers, consumers and other interested groups for much longer than 12 months. The consultations in their major form go back to September 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Affiliation of Voluntary Care Associations, of which most voluntary care organisations, religious and charitable organisations are members, was involved in those discussions and there would have been quite extensive feedback throughout that time. That is an important point to bear in mind when considering the Opposition's amendment, which seeks to provide, in effect, that organisations which have not received Commonwealth capital funding-that is, the 100 per cent resident funded hostels-are not subject to the requirement to accommodate a percentage of financially disadvantaged people. We are talking about approximately 25 resident funded facilities out of 974 hostels Australia-wide. Of these resident funded facilities, 13 are Uniting Church in Australia facilities in New South Wales. As I pointed out in my reply to the second reading debate, the Commonwealth pays, on behalf of the taxpayer, a recurrent subsidy to ensure that all members of the community, including the financially disadvantaged, who need hostel care can get access to such important care. Since 1984 all hostels which have accepted Commonwealth recurrent funding either have been required under the terms of their recurrent funding agreement or have been put on notice to admit one financially disadvantaged person in every five people admitted; in other words, to accommodate a financially disadvantaged person component of 20 per cent. Of course, even prior to this time many hostels have sought to accommodate a percentage of financially disadvantaged persons.

In addition to the five years' notice already given to the hostels of this requirement to accommodate financially disadvantaged persons, the new arrangements have given further special recognition to the position of resident funded hostels by including quite generous transitional arrangements to 1990-91 to allow them to meet the requirement to accommodate this group. That has come out of the consultations and discussions between the Government and the industry. I do not think that the degree of consultation should be understated, nor the frankness and the mutual good intentions of the consultations and discussions which were carried out.

In response to representations made by the Uniting Church during 1988, prior to the commencement of the new arrangements, I agreed to an aggregation arrangement whereby resident funded facilities could aggregate their requirement to accommodate the financially disadvantaged component of 20 per cent across all their facilities. This means that, in the case of the Uniting Church facilities in New South Wales, which is the case in point, this requirement can be aggregated across all 35 of its hostels in that State. People should not take from that that we are suggesting that aggregation means that residents will have to move from one facility to another. That is certainly not my intention. That is contrary to the whole concept of aggregation and certainly to the spirit in which that decision was arrived at.

It is significant that only one resident funded facility in Australia, which is in fact one of the 35 Uniting Church facilities in New South Wales, has not already entered into an agreement with the Commonwealth on the basis of the concessions that have been granted and agreed. The Garrison hostel was not originally capitally funded by the Commonwealth. Its entry contribution is between $150,000 and $240,000. It is perhaps not surprising, therefore, that the financially disadvantaged do not feature in this hostel's clientele. The Government recognises that aspect of the past. In the aggregation proposition that the Government has negotiated with the industry, in particular with the Uniting Church in New South Wales, we recognise many of the problems it has faced in the past and the problems it faces in dealing with the new arrangements which have to be taken into account nationally as well as in specific cases.

I also mention that a study carried out some time ago indicated that the financially disadvantaged had only about 60 per cent of the access to hostel care available to the financially advantaged. Many of the aged in this country do not have access to the more secure or larger forms of self-contributory programs such as superannuation in the workplace, which is now becoming more and more a feature of income security in this country. Many people, because of chronic ill health, because of having a large family and being on a low income over their lifetime, or for many other reasons, have not had access to such programs. This Government is quite firm about and proud of the fact that it supports those people who do not have much money to ensure that, in their old age and when they are frail, they have access to secure and affordable accommodation.

I also mention that, in order to assist organisations to adjust their financial arrangements in the transition to the new requirements, I have offered funding for a consultancy to assist operators, particularly of small homes, to achieve value and efficiency from these new arrangements. Considering our experience of the types of management consultancies that have taken place in the nursing home industry as a way of helping management to adapt to the changes, I expect that the community, and more specifically the hostel operators, will benefit greatly from this consultancy process and, through that, have a better understanding of the new arrangements and how best to make those arrangements work in their situation.

I cannot support the amendment moved by the Opposition on the ground that in effect it has very little to do with the Bill before the House. It is more relevant to the earlier piece of legislation passed last year. I cannot support it also on the ground that I believe that satisfactory arrangements have been reached across the board for resident funded facilities, as evidenced by the agreements entered into by those organisations. In saying that, I recognise that many organisations and hostel operators are unsure of and perhaps lack full confidence in the new arrangements. That is understandable considering what is expected of them to plan for the future and to embark effectively upon a new world.

But I point out that, as with nursing home reform, any of these changes agreed to between the Government and the field will be closely monitored. In fact, we welcome the involvement of the industry and the sector in this monitoring, as we have done in the nursing home arrangements. If it appears that changes need to be made, the Government will make those changes. Having gone to the effort of ensuring the number of hostel and nursing home beds that have come on stream, there would be no value to the Government in seeing those lost because of lack of viability.

This Government certainly recognises the tremendous role played, particularly by the voluntary sector, in providing both hostels and nursing homes. I certainly applaud its effort over years and decades-efforts taken when there was very little government involvement. But times have changed. We are now in the situation of there being greater need in the community and a realisation that that care needs to be extended right across the community, not simply, as in decades gone by, to the lucky ones who had the opportunity to get into some form of aged care.

If further adjustments or transitional arrangements are necessary, they will be introduced as the need arises. Consultation with the industry certainly does not stop with the passage of this Bill. It will be an ongoing process which my officers are keen to ensure continues. That is the way we get feedback and that is the way we can progress with certainty in the future. Considering the very substantial subsidies that the Government, on behalf of the taxpayers, pays to hostel and nursing home operators, I hope that that spirit of cooperation will continue.

A number of people from the Uniting Church, from every State and every organisation, have wanted to see me on this matter and it has been difficult for me to fulfil those requirements. That is why we have departments, and specialists within those departments, to deal with such matters. In relation to the points raised by those opposite, if the Uniting Church, because it feels it is particularly disadvantaged by these arrangements, feels that there are other points that need clarification after my Department has spoken to it, I will do what I can to meet with its members in order to see in what way the Government can help it, as I will do with any other organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister observed that the churches that have received capital funding-I make the point that they are the ones I am speaking about-have had five years notice of this change. He made the point that there might be further transitional arrangements running on until 1990 or 1991. I want to make my point clear because I noticed a letter in the Sydney Morning Herald of 30 December from the Reverend Harry Herbert of the Board for Social Responsibility of the Uniting Church. He referred to aged costs, as the letter was headed. The letter states:

Sir: The announcement by the Commonwealth Government of ``a new deal'' for residents and operators of aged persons hostels may well deceive many aged persons and their relatives. While claiming to help aged persons many will be disadvantaged by this so-called new deal.
He was speaking about those who will have to pay increased fees. The letter goes on:

Residents in hostels which cannot meet the new requirements will face increased charges when those hostels lose Government funding after January 11. Incoming residents in hostels which were built without Commonwealth capital funds face much higher entry costs as those hostels attempt to fulfil the new requirements.
He makes it clear and states:

The Uniting Church, the largest operator of non-profit hostels in New South Wales, is signing the new agreement only under the greatest protest. While the Uniting Church fully supports the basic policies that underline the new changes, it believes that the way in which the changes have been implemented has been mishandled by the department with unintended consequences.

The Minister made the point that all but one of the resident funded hostel managements had entered into these new agreements, but it is clear that they did so under duress. They were told that there would be no recurrent funding unless they signed the agreement. The Minister said, `These are the terms. These are the dates. Sign on the line'. It is not a question of `You really don't have to. This is a fairly jolly arrangement. We're all here to help you. Put your signature here if you like. If you don't, take it to your lawyers. Consider it. Think about it', and so on. It was a question of `Sign and the funding will continue. If you don't, the funding will no longer be there'. If we had some commercial organisation entering into agreements with individuals on that basis, we would be referring the matter to one of the other departments for which the Minister previously had responsibility. I do not think that is the way in which these matters ought to be dealt with. I wrote to the Reverend Harry Herbert. I have met him in other circumstances. I asked him about this matter. He wrote to me responding:
Thank you for your letter of 6 January concerning the new hostels agreement being implemented by the Department of Community Services and Health. The policy aims of this move cannot be disputed.
It was not as though the church was complaining about what the Minister was trying to achieve. Its whole rationale is to help the poor, to help the needy. The letter goes on:

The intention is to ensure that financially disadvantaged persons occupy 20% of beds in hostels and that all persons retained are not stripped of all their assets in paying hostel entry fees. The Uniting Church supports these principles.

However, difficulties arise in regard to hostels which were established without any Commonwealth capital funds. In these cases residents themselves provided capital funds under various arrangements. While the church wishes to make every effort to have lower income persons admitted to these hostels it is very difficult to achieve this at a level of 20% and in respect of persons classified as financially disadvantaged by the Department. The Uniting Church has attempted to obtain flexibility by seeking to be treated as a totality in the achievement of these figures but without success.

Some hostels will have to decide not to accept further government funding and this will mean fee increases for residents. Others will have to re-arrange entry fees so that higher fees will have to be charged.

The purpose of my letter to the Editor was to take exception to the claim by the Minister . . . that the new agreement represented ``a new deal'' for aged persons. Also, our church takes exception to the inflexible way that the agreement has been implemented by the Department.

Finally, I reiterate the question that I raised at the beginning of these comments in relation to meeting with the Uniting Church. I understand that the church has been seeking to see the Minister. I found the meetings very beneficial. I hope the Minister will see them as well and hear from them first hand. I am not trying to heavy-hand the Minister or to make political points-although everything is political in the way we discuss things. They have a difficult task to fulfil. The Minister has to understand these issues. It seems to me that the amendment we are proposing deals with the principle question as to whether one ought to be seeking to rewrite these arrangements retrospectively, whether we ought to be changing them. We are dealing with elderly people who really do not understand these issues. The Government has a particular responsibility to be totally fair and equitable in the way in which it addresses these matters. There needs to be absolute fair dealing with these old people. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address the House on the Crimes (Hostages) Bill this afternoon on behalf of my colleague the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown), the shadow Attorney-General, and I am very pleased to do so. He, I think properly, holds a reputation in this place as a very eminent and learned person in the law. I think it is very good that within the Parliament, particularly from the Opposition's point of view, we do have someone of his calibre to lead debates in the Attorney-General's area. It is not just good for the Parliament; it is good for the Opposition. It is well known that he runs rings around my colleague the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), and I am very pleased to speak on his behalf this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General will be pleased that the Opposition supports this Bill. There is no doubt that it does make good sense for Australia to accede to the International Convention Against the Taking of Hostages. It is the effect of this Bill to incorporate the provisions of that convention into domestic law. To put the convention into effect, the Bill creates the offence of hostage taking and imposed a penalty of up to life imprisonment for the commission of that offence. The Bill defines `hostage taking' as taking a hostage to compel a person, an institution in Australia or an international governmental institution to do something as a condition of the release of the hostage. It imposes a penalty of up to life imprisonment for the offence.

The Bill applies to offences committed in Australia or its external territories, in the Australian coastal seas or on an Australian ship or aircraft, and also to offences committed outside Australia by an Australian citizen, someone present in Australia, or someone who committed the act in order to compel an Australian institution to do or abstain from doing an act. Section 68 of the Judiciary Act requires the prosecutions to be pursued in State or Territory courts. The Bill is intended to be a companion measure to the Crimes (Hijacking of Aircraft) Act, the Crimes (Protection of Aircraft) Act, and the Crimes (Internationally Protected Persons) Act.

The Bill is consistent with the Opposition's law and justice policy and with the Future Directions document which was so successfully launched by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) prior to Christmas. For those general reasons we support this measure. The measure, as is referred to by the Attorney-General in his second reading speech, follows consultations with the States as to its implementation. This cooperative federalist approach which has been picked up in this one instance is something which is very much supported by the coalition parties. I put on record the fact that the coalition parties have an excellent record in the criminal law enforcement area.

We have heard in the last few days that the Government has this seven-seven tactic or strategy and wants to compare its term in government with the seven years of the Fraser Government. I welcome that. It is interesting that, after the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) announced that strategy, within a couple of days he had decided to drop the whole idea. On Sunday, when one would have expected him to be talking about the great efforts of the Hawke Government after six years, he went to the races. As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) said yesterday, the one good thing about that is that when he was gambling at the races he was gambling with his own money for a change.

The fact is that the Opposition is very happy to look at records because the record of the Fraser Government in this area stands out as a very considerable record of achievement and effort. If one looks at institutions in Australia in this policy area, those institutions by and large were either initiated by, established by or followed initiatives of the Fraser Government. I think of the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence; I think of the National Crime Authority, which followed initiatives by the Fraser Government; and let me mention Senator Durack and what a tremendous job he did when for many years he was Attorney-General of this country. I think of the Australian Federal Police in 1979-a tremendous initiative and a tremendous mark of the efforts of the Fraser Government. Kevin Newman was one of the Ministers responsible for that initiative. In the area of counter-terrorism, the Standing Advisory Committee for Protection Against Violence was another Fraser initiative. What a long list it is when one looks at the initiatives of the Fraser Government. It includes the National Police Research Unit and such things as the Australian Police Ministers Council.

It is no wonder that, when some bright spark had this idea to compare the Hawke years with the Fraser years, the whole thing was dropped like a hot potato after a couple of days. Whether it is home interest rates, whether it is a decline in family living standards, whether it is the increasing number of homeless young children in this country, whether it is policies to remove child poverty-whatever one nominates-the fact is that the Fraser Government matched this Government and then went further, when one looks at its tremendous initiatives. In terms of policy for the future, the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) and the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), with a proposal for a national institute of forensic science, have contributed another important initiative which follows on the efforts of the Fraser Government.

Opposition support for this measure is in part based on our concern at the increasing levels of violence in society. I referred to the Future Directions document a moment ago. One of the themes of that document is to reflect a view held by many people in the community that we really ought to be getting back to some basic values.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member should get back to the subject before the House.

—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker. If honourable members would care to turn to the Crimes (Hostages) Bill 1988, they will see that it refers to Australia adopting this convention into domestic law to deal with acts of violence over which this Parliament has jurisdiction. Future Directions outlines a view which is held very widely in the Australian community. People say, `You see things on television, but you never really thought that it could happen to your children'. There has been a bit of a heatwave the last few days and people are saying, `I can remember when in this country on a hot summer's night you could sleep with the front door open'. It is time for us to address some of the fundamental values and try to get back to tin tacks, if you like.
—If you could get back to the Bill too.

—There is no question that it is time that in the area of law enforcement, as it is in the area of government policy generally, we had some plain thinking. Future Directions contains more than 300 policy commitments. One of them is entitled `Stamping Out Terrorism'. The document contains within it-and this Bill is part of the implementation of this policy-the general framework which ought to be adopted by this Parliament in addressing these basic issues. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: There is general agreement among civilised countries that terrorism, both domestic and international, is a growing threat to the security of their governments and people. There remains considerable scope to develop common measures against terrorists, and against governments that sponsor terrorism or shelter terrorists.

To allow the present state of affairs to continue is, by inaction, to aid terrorists. Despite the great political and legal difficulties that confront the securing of effective agreement on co-operative measures against terrorism, it is our view that the dimensions of the problem and the threat it poses to the democracies are such that positive action is urgently required, including an initiative to examine ways and means of securing agreement on internationally agreed penalties on individuals and governments.

Whilst individual countries faced with possible reprisals shrink away from tough action, terrorism will continue to be used as a powerful weapon to debase humanity and paralyse governments. By acting in concert with others the democracies can demonstrate that we will not be held to ransom by those who perpetrate such atrocious acts against humanity.

That is a direct quote from Future Directions which was launched by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) before Christmas. When it comes to providing some leadership and when it comes to reflecting community concerns about the need to get back to basics, traditional values, then this document and its success is founded on that capacity to draw on concerns widely held in this community.

I simply conclude by saying that the Opposition supports this Bill. It is an appropriate measure and, therefore, we give it our endorsement. However, it is but one part of a more comprehensive approach which is necessary. It is an approach outlined in Future Directions, from which I have quoted but one part. With those remarks, I endorse the Bill and commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important that the Crimes (Hostages) Bill is endorsed by the members of this House. It is also very important that it proceeds as quickly as possible onto the statute books. I note the comments made by the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). He talked about the ongoing activities that have taken place under the previous Government and the Hawke Labor Government. It is important that this country is able to accede to and implement the international covenant and convention against the taking of hostages. There are many people out there in the broad community who, faced with fear and trauma when they hear of the hostages that are taken, the crimes that have occurred and the threats to aircraft, are worried about the whole scenario. It is important that we, as a nation, have the legal jurisdiction to deal with this problem. It is also important that we take an apolitical approach to this and that we do not have the Liberal Party and the National Party fighting each other as they often do on so many other issues, let alone fighting the Labor Government.
—You can go back to Queensland now that Joh has retired.
—If we could remain with the Bill.

—I will be commenting on some of the other things that the honourable member for Flinders raised. I am sure that he did not stick to the Bill. He tried to talk about comparisons, and I will deal with that later. There is a need to ensure that we create offences of hostage taking and attempted hostage taking and that some action can be taken against those who participate or are accomplices in hostage taking or the attempt to do so. It is very important that we have jurisdiction over these types of offences in all the sorts of circumstances that can arise in connection with this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased that the honourable member for Flinders has stated on behalf of the Opposition that it supports at least the general intention of this legislation. I say that because there is a very narrow and, unfortunately, very vocal point of view being expressed in the community which is being stirred up by some of the extremist groups on the Right. Regrettably, I have to mention again the League of Rights, because it seems to be groups associated with the League that are part of this. The vocal point of view that is being expressed is that Australia should shun involvement with the United Nations in every way, that it should cast aside any initiative taken at the United Nations General Assembly, that it ought not be part of any international convention or covenant and that we ought just to live our lives alone on this island. That worries me. It is important that these conventions are adhered to. If we are going to play our role as members of a world community, it is important that we participate and are active in these discussions at the world forum. More importantly, when decisions are made in bodies such as the United Nations that are aimed at protecting the ordinary citizens of the world, we should do our bit in bringing down the necessary legislation.

I refer to these extreme groups because it was not so long ago that members of Parliament started to receive letter after letter about how we were part of some sort of convention to disarm Australians. Many people were saying this. Comments have been made at public meetings and all sorts of publications have been produced saying that Australia has signed a document at the United Nations level which will remove the right of any Australian to have a weapon. That is nonsense. The convention that that issue was aimed at was not to disarm Australians. That was a misconstrued, misrepresented position. It was referring to Australian participation in a world effort for nuclear disarmament. It was aimed at trying to reduce the number of weapons-in other words, a worldwide reduction in arms-across this planet. But those who want us to isolate ourselves, who want to keep tearing at the very fabric of this Government, this Parliament and our society, have as their tactic this misconstruction, misrepresentation, of these international issues, just as they did with this so-called move to disarm Australia. It was total nonsense, total lies, but many people out there believed it.

Because there is this consensus between the Opposition and the Government, the major parties-I would hope that the Australian Democrats would be a part of this and I am sure they will be-we need to come together to say that there are those types of issues dealt with at the international forums that we ought to be participating in. It is regrettable that it has taken so long. This was originally enacted at the United Nations in 1979 and it has taken a long time. As the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) said in one of his speeches, it is not up to us to explain why the Opposition when in government did not act on it during the period from 1979 to 1983. We have had a problem in dealing with it ourselves because of the negotiations that were necessary with the States and the Territories. But now we have this legislation that sets down not just guidelines but laws. It gives us the jurisdiction when we are talking about crimes that involve hostages.

Australia is an island. Despite its geography and its position in this world, we cannot isolate ourselves from the rest of the world. We are affected by all the world events, sometimes in major ways, sometimes in a very partial way; but world events have a consequence for this nation. So we need to participate positively as a member of the world community. Yesterday I received a letter saying that we have no right to have a peacekeeping force anywhere in the world, other than in Australia. That is just nonsense, but it seems to be the mentality of some people. I have had letters saying that we should withdraw from the United Nations. I think the people who write letters of that sort have a myopic approach; they are blind to the realities of the world in which we live. I get letters continually saying that we must withdraw our aid. I say that we need to maintain our peacekeeping forces where that is seen to be in the interests of this country.

We need to maintain our part and our role in world forums, particularly the United Nations. We need to maintain our role in providing carefully directed aid. And we need to be signatories to national conventions such as this. Australia has a responsibility to work with the nations of the world to combat the threats to the world, because in doing so we are combating the threats to Australia. That is a responsibility, whether the threat be through famine, poverty, war, or terrorism, which is what we are talking about here. We have to work to deter and suppress terrorist acts. We need to have in place adequate punitive measures. That means enacting legislation to give this Parliament national power. I accept that the States have certain powers in this field, but this is a national problem. We need to face the problem at a national level.

As the honourable member for Flinders said, I believe this Bill is evidence of Australia's willingness to participate in these fields. We have had previous Acts. There was the Crimes (Hijacking of Aircraft) Act in 1972; the Crimes (Protection of Aircraft) Act in 1973. Under the previous Liberal Party and National Party Government, we have the Crimes (Internationally Protected Persons) Act of 1976. So there has been participation on both sides in playing this role internationally and it should continue. There are also recent initiatives that the Attorney-General and other Ministers are involved in-initiatives to ensure that we maintain a role in the discussion at international levels about the way to stop and suppress terrorism at the airports, at the shipping ports, and at our offshore drilling rigs and platforms.

One does not solve these problems by hiding oneself in the island of Australia, hoping that they will all go away. One combats these problems by joining with other nations and working together with them to come up with a worldwide strategy and plan to have the instruments to fight the terrorists on their own ground. I am told that later this year legislation will be brought to this chamber to ensure that these discussions turn into law. We certainly need to approach these issues on a national basis and on an international basis.

There need to be appropriate penalties for terrorism. Also we need to send a signal across this nation and across the world that terrorist acts will not go unpunished. We also need deterrents and legal jurisdiction to be clearly established. I totally support what the Attorney-General has brought to this House. It is very important that the terrorists of the world know that Australia is part of the family of world nations in its efforts to try to put an end to terrorism. One would have to be the supreme optimist to believe that that will happen, but the terrorists of the world have to know that if there is an act that is affecting Australia in any way, then we will have our laws to act against the perpetrators of that act, particularly if it is associated with any airline, any port, or any shipping facility; we will have these powers.

As I said at the outset, terrorism brings fear into the minds of many people. We must act in a coordinated international way to end that fear to the best of our ability. This convention is part of that action and it deserves the support of all members, irrespective of their political persuasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with my colleague the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), who so eloquently has put the Government's position and commitment with respect to this Crimes (Hostages) Bill. The purpose of the Bill is to enable Australia to accede to and implement the International Convention Against the Taking of Hostages. The effect of the Bill will be to create the offences of hostage taking and attempted hostage taking, and participation as an accomplice in hostage taking or attempted hostage taking, and to establish jurisdiction over the offences in a range of circumstances connected with Australia. The offence of hostage taking is defined in article 1 of the convention, which I will refer to in a moment. The offence of hostage taking created by the Bill and the related offences created by the Crimes Act 1914 extend to all prescribed acts committed both within and outside Australia, except those specifically excluded by articles 12 and 13 of the convention.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I turn to the specific terms of the Bill and the treaty which lies at its heart, let me reply to the unsubstantiated allegations made by the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). This debate has ranged quite widely-dare I suggest, trespassing slightly beyond what ought to be the ambit of the debate. I believe that the matters raised by the honourable member for Flinders ought to be replied to. He and his Opposition colleagues ought to hang their heads in shame that they dare to come into this chamber and trumpet the achievements of the Fraser Government. That Government had a sad and sorry record in failing to take up issues involving law enforcement and organised crime. I ask the people of Australia to judge the present Government on its record: The establishment of the Director of Public Prosecutions in March 1984; the establishment of the National Crime Authority; the convening back in April 1985 of the special Premiers Conference on drugs; the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987, involving illegally obtained assets; and the commitment that this Government has brought to bear in making Australia a world leader in relation to extradition.

The fact is that when we came to office in 1983 Australia had one of the worst records in the world. It was only because of reforms of this Government that we were able once again to hold our heads high in the international community. So I say to the honourable member for Flinders that he ought to hang his head in shame if he comes in here supporting the record of the Fraser Government.

The Bill before the House is one that ought to have the bipartisan support of the Parliament. It was not my intention to introduce partisan debate in the course of my remarks, but I believe that the comments of the honourable member for Flinders had to be responded to. As I have indicated, the Bill will enable Australia to accede to the International Convention against the Taking of Hostages, which was unanimously adopted by the United Nations General Assembly on 17 December 1979 and which came into force on 3 June 1983. We in the Government place great store on the potential for international cooperation to resolve a number of the world's problems. The issue of hostage taking, such as that outlined by the honourable member for Capricornia, is one that demands the coordinated efforts of all governments to solve. We are, of course, acting on other legislation to give effect to our international treaties in this area.

Recent initiatives of the Government in this area to combat terrorism include participation in the negotiation of international instruments aimed at suppressing terrorist acts at airports serving international aviation and terrorist attacks on international shipping and offshore drilling platforms. The Government, as the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has said, intends to introduce legislation to implement these instruments in the Parliament. There has been some delay in giving effect to the convention. The major part of that delay has resulted from the need to consult the States and Territories before Federal legislation was enacted. That consultation has occurred and the decision of the Commonwealth has been that we need national legislation for a number of reasons.

The first is that it would not be possible for Australian participation in the convention to be based on existing State and Territory laws. State parties are obliged under the convention to make hostage taking punishable by appropriate penalties which take into account the grave nature of the offences. State law is unfortunately inadequate for the purpose. More importantly, existing State and Northern Territory offences do not have the necessary extraterritorial application required by the convention. A person who commits an act of hostage taking anywhere in the world must, in accordance with our obligations under the convention, be able to be tried, if found in Australia, or to be extradited to Australia if any of the grounds on which Australia is required to exercise jurisdiction apply.

I believe this is an important contribution. It is only one of a package of initiatives that the Government is taking to combat terrorism. I have read and seen, as have other people throughout Australia, some of the horrendous consequences of acts of international terrorism that result in the taking of hostages. To take just one of many examples, there was the case of journalist Terry Anderson, who was the bureau chief of Australian Associated Press in Beirut. He spent the first three weeks of his captivity lying chained to a bed, threatened with death if he uttered a single word. For the next six months he was beaten, kicked and tortured with taunts that his family and government had abandoned him. There is, of course, a new dimension to international terrorism and hostage taking, with the attack on the Achille Lauro with its crew and passengers aboard, which was, as the Sydney Morning Herald said in its editorial, and with which I agree:
. . . political terrorism in its essence: terrorism does not recognise an adversary's legitimacy but seeks to demoralise it with dazzling, spectacular violence.
Those are the sorts of acts that are the subject of the Bill before the House today. As I have indicated, I join with the honourable member for Capricornia in strongly supporting this Bill.

There is one other point I wish to make, and that concerns the terms of the convention concerning the extradition of a person who has allegedly committed a convention offence and who is found in Australia to be subject to extradition to a country where there is a doubt that person may obtain a fair trial. Article 9 of the convention provides that a request for the extradition of a person alleged to have committed a convention offence shall not be granted if the State party to which the request is made has `substantial grounds for believing' that the request was made for the purpose of prosecuting or punishing the person on account of his or her race, religion, nationality, ethnic origin or political opinion, or that the person's position may be `prejudiced' for those reasons. Those concerns, that I think a great many people in the House would have, are dealt with in the Extradition Act 1988, which was proclaimed on 1 December 1988 and, of course, which is in all Australia's modern bilateral extradition treaties. I do not wish to comment further on the Bill. I join Government members and those members of the Opposition who have made a constructive approach to this important debate, in commending the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank all honourable members who have participated in the debate. The Opposition has indicated its support for the legislation and my colleagues the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) and the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) have also indicated the need for Australia to accede to conventions, and particularly the International Convention Against the Taking of Hostages. It is an important convention which relates to the taking of hostages and terrorism. Whilst we would hope and pray that we will never be the subject of such incidents in Australia, that cannot be guaranteed. The United Nations, after looking at instances across the world, naturally wants to get some uniformity in the type of legislation that the world's authorities agree should be implemented. This legislation does just that.

SPEECH.PARA: We have excellent security agencies in Australia which are not able to advertise the problems that they think might be coming our way. They are all very vigilant in an effort to prevent such problems occurring in Australia. So it is important that when we have legislation such as this we get the cooperation of State governments, which we have got as there has been consultation in that respect. There have been arguments, as often happens in a federal structure, as to why we need Federal laws and why we cannot rely on State laws. I think this is an excellent example of the need to have Commonwealth legislation. When we are talking about penalties and the definition of offences, with the greatest respect to the States and the Northern Territory, they have different interpretations and different applications. We might find that penalties vary from what the international convention states ought to be the adequate penalty, in this case life imprisonment. In some States, we might find a narrowing of the definition of kidnapping and matters of that type, which might mean an inability to apply the terms of the convention.

It is for that reason that we feel it is in both the national and the international interest that we act on that basis. In no way should it be interpreted that we are trying to overcome States' rights in the matter. I know that has not been suggested, nor should it be. But it is important to make the point that we also have an obligation under Article 9, as was mentioned by the honourable member for Hughes, that if there are substantial grounds for believing that if an extradition request were made that the person asked to be extradited might well be the subject of punishment on the basis of religion, nationality or political opinion, we have an opportunity to evaluate that situation and possibly regard the person as being prejudiced and we may therefore be unable to agree to the extradition. In other words, the national interest understands all the problems that Australia faces in the world. Basically that was the background of the reason for Federation-that extraterritorially we would act as one nation, and this convention ensures just that. I thank honourable members for their contributions and I commend the Bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition had no difficulties with the substance of the previous legislation. In essence, we will be celebrating the first birthday soon without ever having seen the baby.

The next point I noted in my speech last year was a comment in the second reading speech of the Minister on the 1988 legislation. He said that the charging of the insurance supervisory fee was done to relieve the burden of `taxpayers in general'. The same point is repeated in his speech this year. Just as I am going over a number of points for the record, so too did the Minister, in introducing his legislation, make essentially the same points as he made only a few months ago. Of course, I noted that I thought these were simply crocodile tears from the highest taxing government in Australia's post-war, if not entire, history.

The truth about the Government's treatment of the average Australian family is irrefutable. If one were to give a taxpayer, with a dependent spouse and two children, in receipt of average weekly earnings the same disposable income that he had in March 1983 when the Hawke Government came to power, he would actually need to be given an extra $56 a week. That is what I said last November. The irony is that since then, sadly, the figure has risen to $58 a week. That is the setting. The Minister has again expressed concern and sympathy for taxpayers in general, when the searing reality of this Government is that it is not only the highest taxing government in the history of the nation but also one that has reduced and depressed living standards as a result of its own default, neglect and ill advised policies that have been shown to impact on the overwhelming majority of low to middle income earners.

The Government has been unable to answer the charge that we have levelled at it, supported by the research section of the Parliamentary Library, that if a person in receipt of average weekly earnings were to be given that same disposable income as he had in 1983, he would need a setting of $58 a week. That is outrageous. The Government cannot deny that figure. It cannot deny the simple fact that, at root, it has ripped into Australian living standards.

The last point I made in my speech on the legislation last year also dealt with the wider issues coming out of certain aspects of the insurance industry. I noted the public concern about the operation of the Western Australian State Government Insurance Corporation and Western Australia Inc. I dare say that we will hear a lot more as certain actions are commenced in Western Australia as a consequence of appointments made by the NCSC last year. I noted then the shady deals and the lack of public disclosure. We will get a bit more now. I noted that Western Australian voters would soon have a chance to register their disgust at such activities in the then forthcoming State election. They registered their vote. There was a massive, rarely seen, 10 per cent swing against the Australian Labor Party in that State, with a two-party preferred swing of 6 to 7 per cent towards the Liberal and National parties.

A more important element is that bit by bit the truth is coming out as to what State Government owned insurers have been up to in Western Australia. If it were relevant tonight I would love to give a run-down on public institutions in Victoria and the way in which they have had their fingers in the till. The boys have been trying, like kids in a lolly shop, to get into the public funding through the Victorian Economic Development Corporation and the like. As to whether there is corruption, that will out even more in the months ahead. But here tonight we are dealing with insurance legislation, so I will not discuss that. In terms of what transpired with State owned insurers, the example was set before us. The great worry is that not only has there been a breach of trust in the insurance of Western Australia, but also there is the reality that State Government owned insurers are not subject to the provisions of the Insurance Act, and that the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner has no supervisory role in regard to those insurers. Nonetheless they set a model for those public institutions to follow in terms of prudential management, a model that was not followed in the case of the Western Australian institutions.
As I said earlier, the coalition parties do not oppose these Bills. We hope that they will prove effective in improving the administration and the regulatory supervision of the insurance industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to support the General Insurance Supervisory Levy Bill, the Life Insurance Supervisory Levy Bill, the Insurance Supervisory Levies Collection Bill, and the Insurance Legislation Amendment Bill which we are debating cognately. In general we could say of these Bills that they are aimed at maintaining effective supervision over the general insurance and life insurance industries, and also over insurance intermediaries. The Bills provide for the registration of insurance intermediaries dealing with unauthorised foreign insurers. They also introduce the concept of an appointed actuary.

SPEECH.PARA: The General Insurance Supervisory Levy Bill introduces, in line with the 1988-89 Budget decision of last August, an annual supervisory fee. It says that that fee should be levied on general insurers, Lloyd's, and life insurers. This measure is intended to recover the ongoing costs of supervision of these bodies as described in the Insurance Act 1973 and the Life Insurance Act 1945 by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. As I have said I am pleased to see that the introduction of that annual supervisory levy is not opposed by the Opposition parties. It was a decision announced in the Budget last year and it basically reflects the Government's view that in this industry there is a need, as has been given effect to in previous legislation, for some protective regulation of this industry, and that in terms of meeting the cost of that regulation-the Insurance and Superannuation Commission-there should be some element of user pays. As the Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Peter Morris) made clear in his second reading speech last year, and again this year on the reintroduction of the General Insurance Supervisory Levy Bill, the Government believes that general taxpayers should not have to supervise the cost of regulating the insurance industry. Over recent years the life insurance industry and the insurance industry in general has seen an enormous number of changes. We have seen an increase in the variety of products which are marketed and, consequently, the life insurance business is certainly much more complex today than it has ever been. It is in that environment that the Government believes there is a role for regulation, albeit in a limited way, of this industry, to ensure that the industry itself is held in high regard by consumers. In an era in which there have been rapid changes in the industry we think it is extremely important that consumers ought to be able to have confidence in the industry in which they are investing their savings.

The concept of user pays covers many areas of government activity. The Government has embarked upon a program of recovering some of the costs of regulating an industry which confers benefits on its users. We have done it in relation to other areas of the finance industry such as approved deposit funds and, in relation to another Bill that will be before the House this evening, export inspection where in order to ensure that the quality of Australian agricultural exports meets a certain standard it is necessary for inspection procedures to be undertaken. When this legislation was debated last year, the honourable member for Kooyong and the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) spoke on these matters. None of those matters is particularly pertinent to this legislation, but I think the comments that the shadow Treasurer made about the tax system and about the user pays principle warrant some response. In fact, I reject it quite categorically. If one looks at the performance of this Government and at the relationship of government revenue to gross domestic product (GDP) one will see that it is quite clear-and judged this way by independent analysis-that total government revenues have declined for the last two successive years.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are still high.

SPEECH.PARA: I appreciate that these Bills do not provide the opportunity for a general economic debate. However, the point was raised about taxation. TALK.START.PARA: —The Export Inspection (Quantity Charge) Amendment Bill 1989 lifts the legislative amounts for export inspection of grain and dairy products and removes other items which are now charged on a fee for service basis rather than on quantity. The actual operating levels are not included in the Bill. These are set by regulation and most were increased on 1 October last year. The Bill extends the Government's push towards a fee for service for export inspection instead of a charge per quantity. Of the 174 items now inspected for export, only some dairy products and grain remain on a quantity basis. The current legislative maximum for dairy products is $5 a tonne and the proposed maximum is $10. Grain is split into three groups: bulk grain, which has a legislative maximum of 33c a tonne, will be lifted to $1; bagged grain, which has a maximum of 33c a tonne, will also rise to $1; and containerised grain, which has a maximum of $1.46 a tonne, will be lifted to $5.

SPEECH.PARA: The passage of this Bill will result in the Government regulating to increase the inspection fee for bagged grain from 30c to 47c and containers of grain from $1.46 to $2.95. The fee on bulk grain was increased from 16c to 17c on 1 October last year. I have been advised it will not be increased again before the next annual review. The Department of Primary Industries and Energy claims it has been losing money on bagged and container inspection because the current maximum in the Bill does not allow it to recover costs. It states that residue testing of grain has resulted in a 31 per cent increase in costs. This is a major reason for the large lift in the maximum fee.

There will be no increase in the operational costs of dairy products. These fees actually fell on 1 October last year due to efficiencies made in the service and no change is planned before the next annual review. Many dairy factories now undertake approved quality assurance programs, and the Inspection Service then just monitors the program at a cost of $49 an hour. More factories are moving to this type of inspection and saving costs. The Department anticipates having all grain on a fee for service basis by 1 October this year or earlier. While fees have not been set for this, the current fee for inspection of grain ships is $47 an hour.

The coalition supports the general thrust of the Government's changes to export inspection policy, which actually commenced under the relevant Minister in the previous coalition Government, Mr Peter Nixon; but there are problems, particularly with some horticultural products. While the Government has targeted horticulture as a growth area for exports, the Inspection Service fee is causing untold damage to many budding industries-no crack is intended there-and the Government appears to have filed these problems in the too hard basket.

One example we had recently was Wondabah Orchids Pty Ltd. That is a company that has been caught by the inflexible rules which are, if not ruining, certainly restricting its export business. One of its regular overseas orders is from a small island for about $100 to $150 worth of orchid plants. The inspection fee was previously zero. Now the export attracts the minimum of $47. Of course, the order has been cancelled because there is no profit in it. During the last week in February this company received three inquiries from France, including one via a recommendation by the Australian Embassy in Paris. But there is no way in which that company can send the French a catalogue telling them that for any order there is a $47 charge, and that charge even applies to a sample. There is obviously no hope for any order to be won on that basis.

In the nursery business much of the overseas business is obtained by supplying samples. This allows the buyer to inspect the quality and ensure that plants and flowers will travel well and arrive in good condition. Even those samples attract a $47 inspection fee, and this has caused many nurseries to decide not to try to get into the export market. Yet a private person who wants to take a plant or flower overseas can take that plant to a central place and have it inspected free. Surely the same system could be applied to orders of, say, under $500. The nursery people, as I have been advised, would be happy to take these consignments to a central place and the fee could be abolished or drastically reduced for these consignments. This would also avoid the unbusinesslike way in which inspectors are obtained at the moment. Most nursery people actually have to ring inspectors at night at their homes to arrange for them to come to inspect a consignment.

While the Opposition is in general agreement with the fee for service, we certainly do not agree with the Government's decision to break its promise to recover only 50 per cent of inspection costs from industry. Most industries now have felt the full force of the increase to 60 per cent recovery, and they will not forget this at the next election. It is obvious that it will not end there. The levels of the legislative maximums in this Bill will allow the Government to move up to 100 per cent recovery of costs purely by regulation, once this legislation is passed.

The coalition parties believe that the people of Australia, as well as the exporters, have an investment in exports from this country. The overseas income helps all Australians gain a better standard of living and obviously reduces that terrible trade deficit which we have at the present time. We believe that all Australians should share in those export inspection costs. When the coalition parties are returned to government at the next election, we will reduce the recovery to a maximum of 50 per cent, instead of the 60 or 100 per cent of the present Government, and we will encourage exports by solving the inspection problems of the small and new exporters.

When we talk about 60 per cent or 100 per cent of cost recovery, what are we talking about? Sixty per cent or 100 per cent of what? At the moment there is no accountability back to the exporters who are being forced to pay this increasing percentage of an arbitrary charge. I think in particular of the absurd situation reached with the fisheries section of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, where there is now a 90 per cent recovery, allowing that section of the Department to build an empire within the Department, all on fisheries levies and charges.

In government, the coalition parties will encourage export industries to increasingly self-manage-and self-assure, if you like-and stand by the brand images of their products. I do acknowledge that the Government is also on this path with its quality assurance.

The Government export inspection arrangements should be limited to what is required by international agreements or by importing countries. Outside that, it should be left to the exporter to maintain that quality standard. Our Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) also has a responsibility, as well as its work with the export inspection services, to assist Australian exporters to overcome quarantine barriers and gain access to overseas markets for our exports and also to determine whether imports of plants and animals meet our quarantine protocols. Having seen a variety of examples, I am forced to say that I sometimes wonder whether AQIS has its priorities wrong and encourages imports of doubtful quarantine validity more than it assists exports of our products or assists our exports to overcome other countries' quarantine barriers.

As I said earlier, the Opposition is not opposing the Bill, but we do want to highlight to everyone engaged in the export of agricultural commodities the Government's broken promise that it would recover no more than the 50 per cent cost of this arbitrary inspection levy and also the sly way in which this Bill reveals that the Government is well down the path to 100 per cent recovery, while at the same time the Government claims that it is supporting and encouraging exports. For that reason, I move the following amendment:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government-
(1) for breaking its commitment to recover not more than 50 per cent of the cost of export inspection charges for agricultural commodities; and

(2) for its obvious policy to move to 100 per cent recovery of the cost of export inspection charges for agricultural commodities, as evidenced by the dramatic increase in the maximum permissible levels of this Bill'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—Yes, and I reserve my right to speak.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Export Inspection (Quality Charge) Amendment Bill will make the rate of recovery of costs for export inspection more efficient and equitable. It will place inspection costs on time rather than on the volume of the commodity exported. This reflects the Government's policy to recover 60 per cent of the cost of the provision of inspection services for agricultural export commodities. An expanding number of companies, however, are entering into approved quality assurance arrangements with the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS). Under these arrangements companies undertake to apply mutually agreed quality control procedures. AQIS then limits its activities to infrequent auditing of those procedures rather than maintaining a permanent or regular inspection service. This style of inspection is available to non-meat products and, consistent with the Government's thrust towards industry self-regulation, it is the sole mode of inspection in the case of live fish exports and canned fruits and vegetables. It is intended to extend approved quality assurance (AQA) inspection techniques to the meat sector as agreement with overseas markets permits.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is moving towards fee for service charging for its activities in place of the previous charges per unit of production. That is a positive step. Programs such as AQA and fee for service charging are demonstrating that substantially reduced costs for both government and industry are poss- ible, as well as greater flexibility for industries in adapting to new or changing markets. There is scope for additional cost cutting with the application of those measures to the meat industry, along with the development of a national meat inspection service and the introduction of new technology related to inspection and quality control.

There are eight items of note in this Bill-eggs, fruit other than dried fruit, fruit juice, fruit products, fish, vegetables, vegetable juice and vegetable products-and I would like to concentrate briefly on vegetables. I mention in passing the improved export inspection service which is being offered to the expanding horticultural industry in Bundaberg. The industry has grown from a $14m enterprise to one worth in excess of $100m during 1988. Leading the way in this is the famous Bundaberg tomato crop. Tomato production increased in 1988 by 14 per cent to over 7 million cartons and the value of the crop jumped by 42 per cent to over $83m. Capsicums were the second most valuable crop, being worth a total of $6.46m. Zucchini production is now worth $6.11m and rockmelon production is now worth $5.86m.

The horticultural industry in Bundaberg is now a major source of jobs and income for those living in the Bundaberg district and, more importantly, for Australia. It shows the ability of farmers and others to adjust and to adapt to changing markets. It also shows the potential there is, particularly in the Bundaberg region which has the best and most equable climate in the world for agriculture, particularly the horticultural industry. I believe that as we look towards Asia and its improving living standards in the years to come, we have a massive market that is still untapped. With that will come dollars that Australia will welcome. Of course, it will also mean jobs and security for families in my district.

The industry is constantly on the lookout for export markets and needs to ensure that its product is of top export quality. The industry asked me recently to approach the relevant authority for the location of an export inspection officer in Bundaberg. Inspection is carried out by officers of the Queensland Primary Industries Department on behalf of the Commonwealth. I am pleased that the Queensland Primary Industries Minister agreed to that request on behalf of the industry and that the State Government has acted in that way. It is a very positive step and is a great plus for our district.

Several years ago the Federal Government initiated a country centres study to help define new investment opportunities for development. The study identified the need for the development of sustained export markets in the Northern Hemisphere. It will require very efficient time management of all relevant elements in the marketing process to ensure that products are delivered to these markets in the appropriate off-season times. But there are marketing niches there for a lot of our products.

The expansion of the market will also create important opportunities for various services to be introduced. This will include packing services and the need to establish dedicated export packing sheds. It will need the production of packaging services. Each product will require purpose built packaging materials and containers tailored for specific markets and transports. The study recommended that an export standards branch be established in Bundaberg to help in the promotion of export products. The industry has already demonstrated a flair for international promotion. Its activity displays at Expo 88 were outstanding and a credit to the industry. That demonstrates that we can get up and beat the rest of the world; it just needs a positive approach.

The production of high quality goods from the Bundaberg district will give the horticultural industry the reputation it needs to carve out its name in world export markets. We are already doing that in manufacture and I believe that we will continue to do it in agriculture. The Minister for Primary Industry and Energy (Mr Kerin) has assisted the tomato industry with the approval of an innovative agricultural marketing program grant for local grower Mr Ron Simpson to help him in the export of refrigerated tomatoes.

I believe that the overall cost impact on industry and on the recovery of costs to the Commonwealth will be minor. The saddest thing I have seen today was at Question Time when the Opposition showed that it still has no agricultural policy and no fiscal policy. Indeed, the greatest decision that has helped agriculture has been the floating of the dollar, which has not been recognised by the Opposition. While the shadow Minister for primary industry, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), has told us what he will do when in government, unfortunately he is never going to have the opportunity.
