SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to admit that I was agreeing with the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) until he got to the end of his speech, when I thought, `How pathetic'. I agree that we can and should match the rest of the world in our exports and that we should be working at that. I preface my speech by seconding the amendment moved by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) and explaining in some more detail why it is necessary to move this amendment. It highlights where this present Government, and particularly the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), has been very deceptive in the way it has approached the whole question of export inspection charges.

SPEECH.PARA: As was pointed out by the honourable member for Murray, the Government came to the last election and put up a promise that it would not increase export inspection charges. Come the May statement of last year, for some reason that promise, like so many other promises that were made to primary industries, just got jettisoned. It was like the promise made to the wool industry about the level of government funding for promotion and a number of other promises that could not even see out 12 months, let alone six months. Another broken promise, which I am going to come to in more detail, is the undertaking given to the Victorian Government on the question of the transfer of the Victorian meat inspection service.

It is interesting to note that the Minister in his second reading speech made reference to the fact that in determining the revised maximum rates for quantity charge specified in the Act it has been necessary to set rates of charge at a level which will allow scope for any future response to inflation-which is interesting-or appropriate changes in policy. Those last few words are very relevant. The Opposition is moving an amendment to point out, first of all, that the Government has broken its promise about the 50 per cent cost recovery and, secondly, that, when one looks at the way the maximum level for the levies or fees is going to be set, it allows the Government scope to increase this cost recovery. If one looks at some of the case studies, we find that on butter, for example, the current charge per tonne is $2.39 and the current maximum is $5. That is already more than double the current maximum that can be charged, not is being charged. Yet the proposal is to double that maximum possible charge again to $10. There are other examples. Bulk grain is currently 17c a tonne. The current maximum is 33c, which is almost double the maximum which can be charged. The Government wants to treble that to $1. The current charge for bagged grain is 30c. The proposed charge is to be lifted by over 50 per cent to 47c, yet the proposed maximum is again $1.

What the Opposition has done in moving this amendment is to warn Australian primary producers that the Government does have a hidden agenda-it is not prepared just to move from 50 per cent to 60 per cent, which, as the Minister has already stated, is a fairly arbitrary move anyway-and that it does have plans to increase it further if budgetary requirements force it to do so. All Australians should have a long hard think about this Government and, in particular, about this Minister, who was prepared to go to the people at the last election and say that 50 per cent was the maximum; yet he has already increased it to 60 per cent, and who knows whether it will go further.

I remind honourable members that, as the honourable member for Murray has already pointed out, the coalition has given an undertaking that it will reduce the maximum cost recovery to 50 per cent. I emphasise that we are talking about a maximum, not necessarily the actual amount. To emphasise the ad hoc way that the Government has gone about setting this increase I would like to quote briefly from the Ausmeat Feedback magazine of December last year. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy was being interviewed. He was questioned on the fact that cost recovery had been increased to 60 per cent and asked whether it would move up further. He said:
No, I thought it could stay at 50 per cent, but a 40 per cent subsidy by taxpayers seems reasonable enough. There are some pretty arbitrary decisions.

Those are the Minister's words, `some pretty arbitrary decisions'. In other words, he thought 50 per cent was all right but someone-probably the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-said 60 per cent and the Minister thought, well, that is not too bad, and he went on to say that there are some fairly arbitrary decisions, so presumably he would not be too worried if it happens to be increased a bit more. In fact, as the Minister went on to say:
I used to think 50/50 was the fairest all round, given the statutory requirements of the customer countries.

In other words, the Minister thought that 50 per cent was all right, but he is prepared to give in every time the Treasurer says, `We want a bit more money. Go and get it from the farmers'. What does the Minister do? He says, `Yes, well, look, here is a way to do it'. He went on to say, in this interview, justifying his 50 per cent:
And because there is a public health matter involved I suppose taxpayers should pick up 50 per cent of it.

I would have thought that was a reasonable attitude. It was something that the Minister ought to have had the guts to stand up for in Cabinet. If he believed that 50 per cent was reasonable, why did he not stand up to the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh)? The Minister went on to say:
While I wouldn't use the word trade-off, there was balancing done.

In other words, this Minister-the man of great principle-when it came to raising more money from farmers and extracting a bit out of them, thought 50 per cent was reasonable, but he was not prepared to stand up in Cabinet and fight for the farmers. In view of the track record of this Minister, I think it not unreasonable for the Opposition to move the amendment that we have, pointing out our concern that the Government obviously has a hidden agenda to increase cost recovery to 100 per cent. I noted that the honourable member for Hinkler and the May mini-Budget statement made an interesting reflection on the matter by saying, when the Government increased cost recovery from 50 per cent to 60 per cent, `Greater cost recovery will encourage industry to take a closer interest in how the services are provided and to ensure that overall inspection costs are kept down'.

I ask the obvious question: why is an increase from 50 per cent to 60 per cent going to change anything? Clearly, if there is cost recovery of 50 per cent, that should be enough incentive to make sure that there is a closer interest in how the services are provided and that efforts are made to ensure that the costs are kept down. Increasing the rate from 50 per cent to 60 per cent is not going to alter that. All it is going to do is give the Government an opportunity to use it as another form of revenue raising at the expense of the primary industries. I would also like to allude to another area in which this Minister has shown that his word is not worth a great deal, and that is when the Victorian meat inspection-

—I would point out that in Victoria, when the meat inspection service was handed over to the Commonwealth, an undertaking was given to the Victorian Government and through it to the Victorian Farmers Federation that the cost recovery would not be increased from 50 per cent. The president of the pastoral group of the Victorian Farmers Federation said in a letter to the Hon. Evan Walker, then Minister for Agriculture and Rural Affairs:

SPEECH.PARA: It is disappointing in the extreme that less than two months after the transfer, the Commonwealth has moved to breach the agreement.

I understand that you share our concerns at this attempt, and are to discuss the matter with the Commonwealth.
The Hon. Evan Walker, in a reply to the Victorian Farmers Federation said, in part:
The Federal Minister, Mr Kerin acknowledges there was an agreement for this to occur during his term as Minister.

The intention was that meatworks would be responsible for paying a meat inspection fee, but that inspection fee would no longer be related to the per head charge. Regrettably, some meatworks decided that they would continue to raise that levy and at the same time would pay the Commonwealth under the new fee for service arrangement. Figures that have been produced to me show that in at least five cases these meatworks were making a profit out of this arrangement. TALK.START.PARA: —A blatant disregard of promises.

So we have moved, as a second part of our amendment, that we condemn the Government for its policy of moving towards 100 per cent cost recovery.

SPEECH.PARA: I have pointed out that the Government gave the undertaking. I have shown that the Minister, in an interview towards the end of last year, said that he believed that 50 per cent was a reasonable figure. But he was not prepared to stand up for it in Cabinet. He just walked away from that belief. Within two months of giving an undertaking to the Victorian Government that the cost recovery charges would not be increased from 50 per cent to 60 per cent, he walked away from that undertaking. Therefore the amendment deserves the support of this House and the Minister and the Government deserve the condemnation which the producers of Australia will so rightly give them for the way they have behaved over this whole question of export inspection charges.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to rise in this debate and indicate my support for the legislation which is before the House and my opposition to the Opposition amendment. The basis of the Export Inspection (Quantity Charge) Amendment Bill in a sense arises from the May economic statement, in which the Government announced a policy of 60 per cent cost recovery in relation to costs incurred by the Government in providing inspection services. The Bill before us puts effect to that announcement, and the amendments contained in it allow appropriate levels of charge to be set for effective recovery of costs for export inspection of dairy produce and grain. The exclusion of a quantity charge on certain commodities results from the Government's move towards the recovery of costs on what we strongly believe to be the more efficient and equitable basis of inspection time used rather than the volume of commodity exported.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is sound. It is based upon the principle that there ought to be a contribution by the industry towards the cost of providing export inspection services. In this Bill we have announced an increase in the recovery of costs from 50 per cent to 60 per cent but also a shift away from the quantity based charges which apply to some export commodities at the moment, and we have moved towards what I think in anybody's understanding is a more efficient and equitable basis of charging on the basis of inspection time used, rather than simply on the volume of goods exported.

The Opposition has claimed in this debate, and in the amendment that it has moved, that the Government has some sort of hidden agenda and intends moving towards 100 per cent cost recovery in relation to all the export inspection services. There has been no announcement by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) or any decision by the Government to that effect. Tonight we are debating a Bill which seeks to recover 60 per cent of the cost of inspection. It is worth pointing out to the House and to those listening to this debate that the Opposition, when previously in government, had decided to move towards a much more significant level of cost recovery in inspection services. I think, therefore, there is some agreement across the House that a level of cost recovery is important in terms of a contribution by the industry towards inspection services and towards ensuring that the inspection services which are provided, are provided in the most efficient and equitable way. As I say, there is no hidden agenda. There is no secret decision waiting in the wings to increase this to 100 per cent. This legislation before the House moves the system from a quantity based to a time based system and it lifts the level for recovery for some quantities-I shall return to that point shortly because at the moment we are talking about only some commodities-from 50 per cent to 60 per cent. In all of these changes there has been consultation with the industry. That is an important point.

There have been a number of claims made in this debate by the two Opposition speakers who have so far contributed. I suspect that by the completion of tonight's debate there will be a number of other claims made which are not factually based, which are simply errors of fact. I think that the Opposition, particularly the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), whose contributions in this House are usually well informed and thoughtful, is confusing the legislative limits which have been set in previous legislation with the changes which are announced in this legislation. I will give the honourable member for Wannon the example of the dairy industry, and I refer particularly to the major items of butter and cheese which are exported. The current legislative limit for export inspection charges is $5 per tonne for butter and cheese. The proposed legislative limit is $10 per tonne. But the actual inspection charge which is levied on butter in that industry was $2.42 per tonne in 1987-88. In 1988-89 it is $2.39 per tonne. In other words, despite this legislation, despite the changes and despite the 50 per cent to 60 per cent cost recovery, there has been a reduction in the charge attracted by products in that industry.

Let me give the honourable member the example of cheese. The current legislative limit is $5 per tonne; the new limit is $10 per tonne. The charge for the previous financial year, 1987-88, was $4.48 per tonne; and the new charge is $4.42 per tonne, a reduction in nominal terms and a significant reduction in real terms. Current charges on other elements in the dairy industry are $3.79 a tonne, and the new charge is $3.74 per tonne. So in all of those areas there is in real terms, and indeed in these examples in nominal terms, a reduction in the actual export inspection charges.

I have alluded particularly to the dairy industry, but I make the more general point that all of the 164 export charges are less today in real terms than they were four years ago. I am reliably informed that two-thirds of all of the recoveries in this industry for export inspection charges are for meat. The honourable member for Wannon has a particular interest in the meat industry, which I fully recognise and understand. But if we look at the statistics-and I hope he does before he decides to vote on this amendment later tonight-we see that the charges which are being levied now for meat inspection are 18 per cent less in real terms than they were four years ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why lift the recovery?

—As I said before, the honourable member is confusing the changes which are required under this legislation with legislative limits. Over recent years significant improvements have occurred in the efficiency of the inspection service. The honourable member might not believe that, but if he looks at the figures-and I am telling him that the figures for meat are correct-he will see that they are 18 per cent less in real terms today than they were four years ago.
—Why increase the limit? Why increase it?

—We are increasing the level of cost recovery, but despite the increase in that level, the actual charge for meat inspection is 18 per cent less in real terms than it was four years ago. In other words, producers, the Government, exporters and Australia are better off in terms of a more efficient export service than was being provided some years ago. The point about industry efficiency is important, and it is one of the changes which are embodied in this Bill which is a shift away from the quantity based charges to the time based charges, and it is a shift that we believe is important because it will engender in the industry increased opportunities for further improvements in productivity and efficiency. Seventy per cent of the charges on those 164 products are already on a fee for service basis. In this legislation we are talking about changes to the other 30 per cent. We are trying to ensure that throughout the industry there is a basis for improvement in efficiency in the way in which agricultural export products are inspected.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Wannon also made some points about the domestic meat inspection situation in Victoria. He claimed that the Commonwealth had breached a clear understanding and a clear commitment with the Victorian Government. I can say quite categorically-I say this particularly for the benefit of the honourable member for Wannon, because he has a particular interest in these matters-that because of the transfer of meat inspection services from the State to the Commonwealth, and because of improvements in efficiency in that industry, meat producers in Victoria this year will save $4.5m in meat inspection charges. So the shift from the State to the Commonwealth, coupled with improvements in efficiency that have occurred, despite this change from 50 per cent to 60 per cent cost recovery, will save meat producers in Victoria over $4m.

TALK.START.PARA: —You still broke it. They could have saved more, couldn't they?

—The honourable member for Wannon is quibbling about the point. I would have thought that as sensible members of Parliament our objective in discussing any legislation that comes before the House, particularly legislation which relates to such an important matter as the inspection of exports, particularly in the meat industry, where there have been problems in the past-I do not need to remind the House of that-would be to provide the best possible service at the lowest cost. Despite the honourable member's quibbling and his semantics about this 50 per cent or 60 per cent stuff, what I am telling him is that for export products in total the cost of inspection has declined in real terms over recent years. The reduction in the meat industry has been 18 per cent in real terms over the last four years, and in respect of Victoria, about which the honourable member for Wannon has made a particular point in this debate, meat producers this year will save $4 1/2m in inspection costs.
—They could have saved more.

—Who could have saved more? They have saved $4 1/2m. Someone has to meet the cost; we are trying to apportion the cost in a fair way. All these changes show that with a bit of leadership such as that provided by this Government, with a sound legislative framework, and with new criteria and new arrangements in the inspection of export products it has been possible during the period of this Government to produce demonstrable savings. The statistics are correct. I cited the dairy industry before, in which the charges are less in nominal and real terms. The dairy farmers north of Bendigo-not in my electorate but in the electorate of the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd)-are benefiting from this. Are honourable members opposite telling me that those farmers will complain-in a period in which inflation is rising by 7 per cent but they can have their export product inspected for less in nominal terms and real terms than they could last year? They will not complain. They will be pleased that they are one of the few groups in the community benefiting from reducing costs and charges and not facing increasing costs and charges. I make the same point in relation to the beef industry. As honourable members know, it seems to have the best export potential that it has had for many years, certainly in the short to medium term. The meat industry is doing pretty well. Are honourable members telling me that meat producers, who today are paying 18 per cent less for their inspection services, are going to come to the Government and complain and be unhappy about the 18 per cent real reduction? They will not. Similarly, in Victoria producers have saved $4 1/2m in the last year. So I reject the Opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, the Opposition seems to oppose everything. Seven months ago the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), promised that they would bring before this House detailed proposals to take to the people in the next election campaign; that they would put forward detailed proposals in relation to taxation matters. We are still waiting. We are all holding our breath waiting for the Opposition's policies to come forward. It is easy for those in opposition to oppose every bit of legislation that comes before the House, and this is a classic example of that. They are saying something is going up, so it should be opposed. Their chance will come when they release their policies.

Despite an increase from 50 per cent of cost recovery to 60 per cent, a change which this legislation gives effect to, the producers in most industries-and particularly the beef industry, in which the honourable member for Wannon has a interest-face reduced charges. I would have thought that as sensible members of parliament we ought to be implementing in this place sound legislation which can produce savings over time for our export industries. That is what this Government has done. I support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to participate in the debate on the Export Inspection (Quality Charge) Amendment Bill and to follow the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby), particularly in view of the audacity of his closing remarks. With the sort of confidence that we have come to expect from the honourable member for Bendigo, with an air about him that, if you will pardon the pun, suggests that butter would not melt in his mouth, he tells those of us sitting on this side of the House and in the gallery that all the Opposition has done is oppose. In this very week Ministers, including the Minister responsible for this legislation, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), have come into the House and commended the Opposition-particularly the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), I might add-for not just opposing Government legislation. So the honourable member for Bendigo had better decide on which side his bread is buttered. At that point I will stretch the pun no further.

SPEECH.PARA: This nation, as shown by the January balance of payments figure, faces a real problem. The Government has to be bothered, as the Opposition is bothered, about a $1.5 billion balance of payments deficit when in January 1988 it was only $0.5 billion. We are bothered because, as the next government of this nation, we are inheriting a problem that will be difficult to address. If this nation needs anything right now it is an increase in its export income. We need to be exporting not iron ore but steel or motor cars; not wool but suits; and not bulk wine but quality product.

Of all the areas in which we have an opportunity to address the problem of a falling export income, the horticultural and floricultural areas are the classic examples. Let me illustrate this point by drawing to the attention of the House some comments made by Mr Barry Waldeck, one of Western Australia's leading nurserymen. When he spoke in Canberra at the National Agricultural Outlook Conference on the future of floriculture in Australia, he told the delegates that Australia presently holds only 0.06 of the world flower trade and that a 2.5 per cent share of that market would be worth $100m a year. At the same time, he said, it should be taken into account that the floriculture market is increasing at the rate of $400m a year. To provide some encouragement-note that word-to potential growers, Mr Waldeck noted that Holland, which holds 63 per cent of the world flower market, speaks of Australia as an untapped goldmine of unique flower species. The home consumer market cannot go unnoticed. The Norwegians currently head the list as the world's largest flower consumers. With a remarkable $65 a year per head of population being spent on flowers in Norway, Australia's $10 per head serves only to highlight the enormous potential which exists in the floriculture market.

I open with that illustration because it highlights the point so graphically made by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) when he gave the example of the Wondabah orchid growers, who are involved in the export of orchid plants and who are more than a little concerned about the legislation before the House because it is such a disincentive to the exporters of floricultural product. Right now, when more than anything else we need to be exporting valuable product, when more than anything else we need to be earning export dollars, we are putting, as is reflected by this legislation, real pressure on new exporters. Worse than that, acute pressure on exporters of small packages of produce is reflected by this legislation. The $47 minimum fee for the inspection of horticultural product is a real disincentive, particularly to those who choose merely to send a sample of their product overseas in order to open some new market. The honourable member for Bendigo said that this legislation `should engender further improvements in productivity and efficiency'. Far from engendering further improvements in productivity and efficiency, this legislation discourages people from entering new and innovative export markets.

The honourable member for Bendigo said, `This legislation is all about cost recovery'. He gave illustrations of what he said were demonstrable savings, particularly to the dairy industry, as a result of the changed attitude to export inspection cost recovery. How thick does he think I am?

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't ask leading questions.

—I will not respond to the interjection by the honourable member for Ballarat. In fact, as the honourable member for Wannon and the honourable member for Murray have clearly said, under this Government export inspection cost recovery has gone from 50 per cent to 60 per cent. I do not doubt what the honourable member for Bendigo says about the Export Inspection Service being more efficient. I simply make the point that cost recovery has gone from 50 per cent to 60 per cent, and that not all of that efficiency in cost saving has been felt by the producers, whose produce we desperately need to service growing export markets. No-one says that the concept of a fee for service is bad in itself. The question is: Who determines the appropriate level of service and who determines how efficiently that service is delivered?

SPEECH.PARA: I turn briefly to another aspect of this legislation. I represent industries that are enthusiastic about a level of self-control and self-regulation in the export industry. No-one expects the Government to back off from inspecting export products. Australia's reputation is at stake. But let us not lose sight of the fact that every producer who is in a long term-and most primary production industries are long term-productive industry has a commitment to exporting quality product.

Let me illustrate that point. An industry that I represent, the wine industry, has set up its own code of conduct in the last month or so in order to minimise the regulation that the Government would otherwise feel obliged to impose on it and in order to minimise the cost that it would face for export inspection. It has decided on a self-regulatory technique to measure quality control and to ensure that the label, the appellation, of Australian wines is accurate. I commend that industry and all other export industries for the effort they are making to be self-regulatory. Once again, I point out to the honourable member for Bendigo and to the Government that we do not oppose the concept of fee for service. We do not oppose the concept of some form of export inspection. The Opposition's second reading amendment stresses the point that, no matter what the honourable member for Bendigo or the Government says, cost recovery has gone from 50 to 60 per cent. The savings that the honourable member for Bendigo alleges have been made have not been channelled back to Australia's productive primary industries.

The Bill before the House is a further push towards a fee for service for exports inspection instead of a price per quantity. Of the 174 items now inspected for export, only dairy product and grain remain on a quantity charge basis. The Opposition does not oppose this legislation. It is concerned only that the Government has not been frank and honest in the way in which it has presented it to the House. I conclude by saying that I support the second reading amendment moved by the honourable member for Murray which highlights the two-faced approach that the Government has taken to the export inspection of primary products. It reads:
``whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government-
(1) for breaking its commitment to recover not more than 50% of the cost of export inspection charges for agricultural commodities; and

(2) for its obvious policy to move to 100% recovery of the cost of export inspection charges for agricultural commodities, as evidenced by the dramatic increase in the maximum permissible levels of this Bill''.
I support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Export Inspection (Quality Charge) Amendment Bill and oppose the second reading amendment moved by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). To put it mildly, the Opposition has taken an unbelievable position tonight. It was good to hear from the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) that the Opposition does not oppose the Bill. Therefore, that must mean that it does not oppose the fact that this Bill must be passed so that the 60 per cent cost recovery measure will be implemented. The Bill does not go beyond 60 per cent cost recovery. The Bill covers only a few items in regard to which the maximum charge limit is likely to be reached in the near future; that is, some rates of charge will exceed the maximum statutory limit because of normal inflationary movements, so we need to set down some ambit to avoid constant amending of the legislation. If this legislation were not passed, we would have to make adjustments at regular intervals in order to satisfy the intention of the law.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill deletes a number of quantity based charges. It is important to understand that the industry has moved to beneficial fee for service arrangements. If one listened to Opposition members one would think that they are opposed to the fee for services concept, whereas in actual fact, for many years they have had a policy which is identical to that which the Government is implementing at present. In fact, for several years they had a policy for 50 per cent cost recovery. However, they were not capable in government of achieving that target, and the taxpayer had to subsidise their inability to collect.

Seventy per cent of 164 charges are already recovered on a fee for service basis. Notwithstanding the move from 50 per cent to 60 per cent, the amounts paid today are less than in previous years. The honourable member for Wakefield did not bother to cover some of the facts in relation to this matter. Other Opposition members have not done so, either. In real terms, charges for meat-which is one of our major export industries and two-thirds of all charges are made in this area-cost 18 per cent less now than they did in 1984-85. I understand why the Opposition is not opposing the legislation. It is facing reality. Opposition members are speaking for the sake of speaking tonight. This Government, and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) in particular, have put in place policies that will lead to a massive change for a major industry in Australia; that is, meat inspection. This is a big issue. Two-thirds of inspection charges stem from the meat industry, yet the costs are 18 per cent less today than they were in 1984-85. That is a truly remarkable performance in anyone's language.

In my State of Victoria the industry is paying $4.5m less this year in meat inspection charges. That is a massive improvement. For the Opposition to move a second reading amendment when, in all honesty, it could not oppose the legislation, shows that it does not have much to fly with in relation to policy. Many people would be interested to know that at the last election the Opposition went to the people with a policy for a zero per cent inspection charge. For many years its policy was for a 50 per cent charge. It has now returned to that policy for a 50 per cent charge. Because the Opposition does not oppose the legislation, we can assume from the speeches that have been made tonight by Opposition members that they are quite in favour of the legislation. No doubt their policy has been adjusted to reflect what the Government is doing. This shows that they do not have much to fly with in relation to policy. They certainly have nothing with which to go to the people in an election year in relation to these issues.

The public subsidy for all export inspection is still some $70m per year. It is a considerable amount because we still believe that the inspection of our export industries is vitally important to the nation as a whole. This Government has never backed away from that issue. We have always believed that some industries are quite capable of paying part of the inspection charges. The honourable member for Wakefield said that the Opposition would inherit what he called the problems of government-in the event of some unfortunate circumstances, and I doubt that that is a real possibility-and that this nation would need export income. It certainly did need export income when we came to power. We went through a period where even though we increased exports, we had a collapse in commodity prices, which, whilst we were exporting more goods, did not increase our income in any way. We inherited a situation in which exports were vital to Australia. Rural exports have always been the key to Australia's economy. However, the Opposition has always failed to support the export industries that Australia has had since it was first settled by white people. We have always relied upon wool, wheat, meat and, in later years, coal. But the Opposition did not put in place the manufacturing base support that we needed. In fact, the legacy it left to us was a manufacturing industry which had been absolutely destroyed. So it was very interesting to hear the honourable member for Wakefield talk about inheriting problems. We certainly have improved the situation for exports right across the board.

A few years back when the commodity price collapse occurred and when I was chairing the rural task force for the Government, I witnessed first hand just how dramatic the effects were of a collapse in commodity prices on not just the farming sector but all those reliant upon the income from those commodities. Today we are dealing with the opposite problems. I can clearly remember in 1974, before I came near this Parliament when I was working a farm of my own, that it was under the Whitlam Government that I made the greatest income I ever made as a farmer. It was the year I paid the biggest taxes I ever paid as a farmer. I never begrudged paying those taxes for a moment, because if one is paying such taxes one is earning a good income. If honourable members ask Australian farmers whether they consider that the situation today is better than at any other time in Australia's history-except perhaps for the woolgrowers in 1951-52 after the Korean War when there was a wool boom-they will say that today's figures would match the wool boom of the 1950s. What we are dealing with is not the problem mentioned by the honourable member for Wakefield of the need for export income; we are dealing with the results of that export income pouring into Australia. That is the real issue in the economy. In that context there are not too many farmers who would begrudge the fact that they have to pay some of the inspection charges in order to ensure that the products which we keep putting on to the world markets are of top standard.

The Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy), who is at the table, has just come back from negotiations overseas. He would be able to tell this House about the importance of quality in our trade. Export inspection is vital to that. It is vital that industries pay their fair share of the costs of that. The taxpayers who are contributing $70m per year at present certainly are not dipping out on what they are prepared to put in. The Government is seeing that they are putting in their fair share. Opposition members say that they do not oppose the Bill. However, I cannot accept the Opposition's amendment, which states:
. . . whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government . . .

It condemns the Government for allegedly breaking its commitment to recover not more than 50 per cent of the cost of export inspection charges. Let me remind the House once again where the Opposition has gone in relation to that policy. It had a 50 per cent inspection charge for years but never got to that point. It let the taxpayers pay it. When we came to office the Opposition had not even reached its own policy. I remind the House again that Opposition members went to the last election trying to win votes by abolishing export charges, yet here they are back in the Parliament saying that they support the Bill. Opposition members are willing to accept that the charge needs to go to 60 per cent, but they want to condemn the Government for breaking some commitment. No matter what industry rural people work in-except perhaps those in the wheat industry, where there is a great debate going on between the Liberals and the Nationals about what is the best policy; the fee for service, the free enterprise approach; less of this dogmatic, agrarian socialism which has been peddled in this country for so long, which even the farmers today will not give credibility to-they are firmly of the belief that this Government has done more to put agriculture on the correct footing on a trade basis. Not only that, but we are creating a basis of support within Australia for a manufacturing base so that if there is in the future another downturn in commodity prices we will not be reliant solely upon the agricultural industry. It is something we have neglected. What did we do with our wool for many years? We sent it overseas and let somebody else process it. What do we do with other products? We dig them out of the ground, send them overseas and then buy them back. This Government is working assiduously towards putting in place programs which will overcome those very issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to join my colleagues the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) and the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) in addressing the Export Inspection (Quality Charge) Amendment Bill and in supporting the amendment which has been moved by the honourable member for Murray, the Deputy Leader of the National Party. He started his contribution to the debate by saying that the Opposition has decided not to oppose this legislation but that it proposes an amendment which says that it condemns the Government `for breaking its commitment to recover not more than 50 per cent of the cost of export inspection charges for agricultural commodities'. That is the amendment we are moving in relation to this legislation tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for McMillan said that he thought it was an unbelievable decision-absolutely outrageous that we should be condemning the Government for breaking one of its election promises. This is indicative of the sense of values that Government members have in relation to campaign promises. In the last election campaign we had a firm commitment from Labor that it would not increase the cost of export inspection services from their then levels of 50 per cent. Tonight the House is dealing with an issue which directly breaks that firm commitment made by Labor during that last election campaign. We on the Liberal and National Party side of the House believe that the breaking of commitments and promises is important and should be highlighted to the people of Australia. We wish to highlight them by moving amendments to draw to the attention of the people in the rural industries of Australia, and people right throughout Australia, the utter hypocrisy they have to suffer from this Government, which continually breaks promises such as this one.

We have had a retinue of other promises made by Labor over the last few years that have been broken in a similar cavalier fashion. In recent days we have heard the debate about child poverty. We were promised that there would be no child poverty by 1990. That is a promise we can throw out the window. We had the promise of no capital gains tax. So many promises have been broken. The amendment the Opposition is moving is designed to draw to the attention of the people of Australia the cavalier manner in which this Government goes about trying to fool people in the electorate with promises made at election time in order to win votes, with the full knowledge that later on down the track when it gets back into government it will break these promises and get on with the job of getting further and further into the pockets of the rural producers of our nation.

The honourable member for McMillan also said that this Government was responsible for improving our export income. I make the point that unless this Government has a great deal more control over events than I think it has, it would have to agree that improved weather circumstances have helped to improve Australia's export income. Indeed, improved worldwide commodity prices have helped to improve our export income dramatically. Neither of those events have been influenced by this Government. Neither the weather nor world prices for our commodities can be reasonably claimed to be the product of this Government's policies. It is purely and simply good fortune that the Government has been able to enjoy improved export income receipts as a result of our rural industries having these improved weather conditions and higher prices for their products.

It is important to note that the Bill before the House relates to the industry which is the backbone of Australia's economy. Historically, it is a fact that Australia has lived off the sheep's back, and we can broaden that term to include the rural industries as a group. Today that is no different. Today Australia still lives off the sweat, the hard work and the investment of the people in our rural industries. There is no more important a time than today for a government to be trying to encourage these industries to create more export income. Despite the improved commodity prices and better weather conditions we have had we still see our economy in a total shambles. We have had balance of payments deficits of $1.5 billion for the last month. This is an horrific record high level. It is this type of problem which Australia faces and it is this type of problem which can be addressed only by creating more export income.

Unfortunately, the Bill before us tonight is doing exactly the opposite to that. This Bill actually increases the costs of production for our exporters and as a result makes us less competitive on the international market. Because we are less competitive we have less opportunity to find markets for our products to bring back income for Australia. That is what this Bill is all about. That is why the Opposition is bringing these amendments before the House tonight. I think it is terribly important that the people of Australia understand that. We are doing this to highlight the hypocrisy of the Government in its broken promises and to highlight the urgent need to encourage our export industries rather than discourage them with additional costs of production.

As a member of the National Party I have a rural electorate which produces a wide range of agricultural products. The meat industry is a very significant one. We also have a number of new and very exciting industries starting to develop at present. I speak particularly of the cherry industry, which over the last couple of years has been developing quite an extensive export industry. Young, of course, is the cherry capital of Australia. One of the things that has been of great concern to the exporters of cherries in that town is the high costs of export inspection services for the products they send overseas. In addition, there are difficulties with getting air freight at a reasonable price, and indeed with some certainty, in order to get their products overseas. This sort of industry is developing in my home town of Young, and there are other new and exciting export industries developing in the area. In Crookwell some people are trying to establish a seed potato industry so that they can compete in a worldwide market that is worth hundreds of millions of dollars, selling seed potatoes to the rest of the world. We have the purest seed potatoes in the world and we are trying to establish that market. All of these added export inspection costs will discourage the type of initiative and investment and income that can be generated from these new and exciting industries that are occurring in my area alone.

It is undeniable that this legislation will actually increase costs for producers. The cost of export inspection services is rising from 50 per cent to 60 per cent of the total cost. That is what this legislation does. We should make no bones about it. Despite all the fancy talk of those Government members who have spoken tonight, who try to tell us that it is going to be cheaper, we cannot deny the fact that if we increase the cost of export inspection services from 50 per cent to 60 per cent of the total cost it will actually increase the cost to producers. That is an undeniable fact. It is going to weigh very heavily on the shoulders of the industry in the years ahead when seasonal conditions are not as kind and when world commodity prices are not as good as they currently are.

I will highlight some of the changes that will occur to the cost of export inspection services. Bulk grain, which currently has a legislative maximum of 33c a tonne, will have its charge lifted to a maximum of $1 a tonne. Bagged grain has a legislative maximum of 33c a tonne and will rise to $1 as well. Containerised grain, which has a legislative maximum of $1.46 a tonne, will be lifted to $5 a tonne. Those are the sorts of maximum increases that we see being put by this Government in the legislation before us and undeniably they will be an extra cost to producers. Growers have had to suffer these sorts of increases over a long period under this Government, coupled with all sorts of extra cost inputs such as the cost of fuel. The excise this Government is imposing on fuel has increased from 6.155c per litre to 22.39c per litre. I might add that unfortunately very little of that goes towards road improvements these days. These cost increases, coupled with the export inspection charges under the Bill before the House, make life for our exporters very difficult indeed.

Growers and rural industry people throughout this country have suffered incredible increases in the cost of services. At the same time in recent Budgets they have suffered incredible decreases in the schemes that encourage export growers and producers. We have seen the superphosphate bounty cut out, costing farmers $37m. We have seen the sugar industry suffer cuts of $8.4m. The wool promotion scheme has been cut by $10m. Depreciation allowances were reduced in 1983 in the first mini-Budget and in 1988 in the third mini-Budget. All these things are costing growers dearly.

All our concerns here today relate to this Government's breaking of promises made to rural producers throughout this country. We are concerned because we need to be encouraging export producers at a time when our balance of payments deficit is in dire straits. It comes at a time which is fortunate for us on this side of the House because it enables us to highlight to the rural producers of Australia that we, on this side of the House, will be able to deliver far better services at cheaper prices to producers with our policies than this Government is doing. Our commitment to keep export inspection service cost recovery to 50 per cent is indeed a far better deal than this Government is giving. This promise will be kept and will deliver substantial benefits to export producers and rural producers throughout Australia.

We have heard all sorts of claims being made by the Labor Party tonight. Basically, it is trying to say that its promise was not really a promise-something not to be taken seriously-and that our amendment is not worthy of consideration. I treat that as it should be treated-with utter contempt. Government members have also tried to point out to us tonight that producers will save with these Bills before the House. In fact, producers will suffer increased costs as a result of this legislation. At the same time, the Government in so ignoring the amendment that the Opposition parties put to its legislation tonight, treats with disrespect and dishonour the industries which have carried this country from its pioneering days to its point of prosperity today and which will continue to carry our nation for the future; that is, the rural industries.

Unless we have a government that is prepared to provide incentives and give encouragement and can reduce the cost of inputs to producers, Australia will continue to suffer the huge balance of payments deficit that it has suffered continuously over the last few years under a Labor government. Unless we get a change of government, we will not see those balance of payments figures reduced; we will not see the cost of inputs for farmers and rural producers throughout this country go down. At the end of the day, the people of Australia will be substantially worse off.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation before the House is putting primary industry on a businesslike basis. It is ensuring a level of efficiency in that industry that we can be proud of. It is not propping up any inefficiencies. The movement towards fee for service will ensure that the primary industry sector is very conscious of the need for efficiencies. That is extremely important. It is quite interesting that the Opposition indicated in the last election campaign that it would cut out all inspection charges-a zero charge.

It is very interesting to note that the Opposition is today saying `Shock, horror' because we are ensuring that there is at least some market relationship between the cost recovery and what is being charged. The shock horror is now at a base of 50 per cent. That is what is in the Opposition's amendment. I can assure honourable members that if the Opposition moves as quickly as that-from zero to 50 per cent-it will bypass anything that we are putting into place at a very rapid rate. It will get to 100 per cent quick smart. What we are moving towards is something which is more realistic. We do not make any excuses for that and the industry recognises this. Sure, there will be some people who will say, `Is it not terrible that we are going to have to pay for this and the taxpayers of Australia are going to be relieved of that burden to ensure that our industry is efficient?'. That seems a rather odd kind of logic. It is inappropriate. I believe that those people in the industry who are serious about their industry will see this as a very appropriate direction in which to go.

The Bill does in fact build in the possibility for improved efficiencies; it makes all those farmers who perhaps currently would like to have someone else pay it all for them recognise that they have a responsibility; but it also enables them to take another hard look at what will be done in the inspection service to ensure that it is done properly. Those farmers now have a vested interest in ensuring that the best kind of inspection service is put in place. They also can rest assured that, because they have a good inspection service and they are paying for it, those who might be inefficient and who fall foul of the inspection service will be called to account. There is nothing wrong with that. That is very desirable. I know that, when I talk to my farmers and explain this to them, they are on side with this proposition. That is extremely important.

It is interesting just to take a look at some of the figures of the rates that are currently being charged. The current legislative limits on butter, cheese and other dairy products is $5 per tonne. The proposed legislative limit is $10 per tonne. That means that we do not have to keep on bringing in amendments all the time, which would be very confusing. In 1987-88 the actual charges were $2.42 per tonne for butter, $4.48 per tonne for cheese and $3.79 per tonne for the other products. In 1988-89 the charges had been reduced, in the case of butter to $2.39 per tonne, cheese to $4.42 per tonne and the other products to $3.74 per tonne. The current legislative limit for grains is 33c per tonne; the proposed legislative limit is $1 per tonne.

This enables some flexibility in the program, again enabling us to make adjustments without constantly making reference to new pieces of legislation. In 1987-88 the charge was 16c per tonne, although the legislative limit was 33c per tonne. In 1988-89 it is 17c per tonne, which again is marginally different, but still only a percentage of that 33c per tonne. And so it goes on. It just indicates that the recovery rates that we have had have not been excessive. These new recovery rates will raise the amount to enable a more realistic set of figures to be charged. With these more realistic figures, again the emphasis is on the industry's levels of efficiency. It is to the industry's benefit. It ensures quality products for our markets overseas and it brings the industry in to it as a necessary partner.

It is not something in respect of which we are going to say, `The other Australian taxpayers will pay for it and we do not have to worry too much about quality'. It is a very businesslike approach. I do not see why business people should be concerned about someone else paying for it; it is the business people themselves, the farmers, who are the ones who will be the beneficiaries, and they will be the ones who will ensure the efficiencies in the industry. Because of this level of efficiency, the Australian economy will benefit in the long run as well. I do not accept the Opposition amendments. The amendments really and truly are an example of-

Absolutely nothing. Who is having to pay? Australian exporters, the rural sector, and this Government does not care. It wants us to pay full cost recovery for export inspection fees. It is imposing on the rural exporter an unrealistically high Australian dollar. It is imposing on the rural exporter a stupid waterfront situation, about which it does absolutely nothing. It expects us to pay the tariffs on imported goods, which are inputs to the cost of rural production and exports. In all these ways it is expecting the rural sector to pay an unrealistically high burden without reducing the cost inputs to the rural sector.

There are a number of areas where this Government has imposed additional taxes and charges that have significantly impacted on those industries' ability to export. This Bill is about increased inspection charges. It covers areas such as dairy and grain products. We had increased inspection charges recently imposed on horticultural products. We have got the ridiculous situation now where the Government has imposed minimum charges on horticultural exports to such an extent that many of the smaller horticultural exports are no longer viable. We have many instances of innovators trying to open up new export markets-cut flowers, fruit, vegetables, nursery stock and so on-and they are hit with this enormous minimum export inspection charge which undermines the viability of their operation. It is just ridiculous for this Government to call on exporters to increase their effort to export more rural products while at the same time imposing these high inspection charges which undermine the viability of such exports. We have just got to look at these industries and give them an opportunity to self-regulate. They know that if they do not deliver a product that meets the market demand overseas they will lose the sale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to address the House on an issue of significant concern to the people of my electorate and to many people elsewhere in Queensland and Australia. I refer to the issue of a bridge to Russell Island, which is situated in my electorate. Russell Island is one of the many islands in Moreton Bay which fall within my Federal electorate and is well known throughout Australia. Although a lot has been said about some of the bad blocks of land that have been sold up there, the vast majority of the island is beautiful. There are drainage problems, but they are in the minority.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make it quite clear from the outset that I am neither pro nor against a bridge connection to Russell Island. Neither I, as the Federal member for the area, nor the Federal Government really have any jurisdiction in this area. Put simply, the issue is one which the State Government of Queensland should decide, in consultation with the people of the island and the Redlands Shire Council on the mainland.

The Queensland State Government, however, has avoided making a decision on the question of a bridge to Russell Island for some 30 years. The reason I speak tonight on this matter is that some of my constituents from Russell Island, in complete desperation and frustration with the National Party State Government's inability to make a decision, have called on the Federal Government and, in particular, on the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), to help fund a bridge linking Stradbroke Island with the mainland.

The dithering on the part of the State Government-this is something for which the current temporary Premier of Queensland, Mr Ahern, is becoming renowned-has allowed speculators, property developers and real estate agents to tell the people wanting to buy land on the island what they have wanted to hear. In the case of the many people who want to live on a secluded island, land sellers are able to say that there will be no bridge. On the other hand, many people, particularly elderly people, have bought on the basis of assurances from the developers that access to the mainland would be provided in due course. This situation has led to successful speculation and rapidly rising prices which do not reflect the real value of the property, particularly considering the very poor state of the services provided by the local authority, the Redlands Shire Council.

The people who want a bridge to Russell Island are predominantly members of a group calling itself the Russell Island Development Association (RIDA). This Association recently held a meeting and, as I have mentioned, a call was made to the Federal Government to provide financial support for the construction of a bridge. Its argument is put in the context of the current expressed desire of the Federal Government to increase the supply of land suitable for housing. RIDA argues that there are potentially some 10,000 blocks of land on the island.

While I can appreciate this group's desire for a bridge, and can sympathise with its frustration at the inexcusable indecision displayed by the State Government, I am afraid that this is simply not a matter for the Federal Government. Even in cases where the Commonwealth is willing to sell land which it owns, it requires the States to provide the necessary infrastructure or, at the very least, enable development to be fast-tracked. I understand that the group has written to the Prime Minister, and he will no doubt provide a response in due course, but it would surprise me if the Prime Minister were willing to fund the building of a bridge to Russell Island because of the factors I have outlined.

As I previously stated, I can completely understand the frustration being experienced by the residents of the island, both those who are for and those who are against the bridge. Their frustration is heightened by the fact that they pay rates, the same as anyone else in the Redlands Shire, but receive only a fraction of the services they need from the Council. The issue came back on the agenda last year in May, when Deputy Premier Bill Gunn announced that the State Government supported, in principle, the construction of a bridge and that expressions of interest in its construction had been called for. This prompted the State National Party member and Queensland Attorney-General, Paul Clauson, to announce, via the front page of a local newspaper, the Bayside Bulletin, that a bridge would definitely be built. This was followed two weeks later by a statement from Mr Gunn that it was all a mistake and that expressions of interest for a bridge to Russell Island had not been called for.

To add to the confusion, the Premier said recently that the Government was not ready to issue a firm statement on the possibility of a bridge. The reality is that the Queensland State Government has been dithering on this matter for so long that it has been fraudulently deceptive in its approach to the whole question. Real estate agents have been selling land on the island for many years on the understanding that a bridge would be built. I call on the State Government to do the right thing and to make a decision once and for all, so that the people on Russell Island, whether they are for or against a bridge, will at least be able to carry on their normal lives knowing exactly where they stand. The whole thing is a disgrace, and something should be done about it quickly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R. L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to bring to the attention of the House the plight of a husband and wife who live in my electorate and who have suffered enormous financial losses because of what is clearly an unsatisfactory system of arbitration of building contract disputes which can lead to biased and unfair decisions. In August 1984, Mr Joe and Mrs Irene Onorati, who live at Drummoyne in my electorate in Sydney's inner west, entered into an agreement with Phillips Construction Co. Pty Ltd to erect five home units on their land at Drummoyne. The contract was what is commonly referred to as a standard building contract BC3. Upon completion of the building Mr and Mrs Onorati received advice from architects, engineers and the Builders Licensing Board that there were many defects in the building, some of them quite serious. Understandably, Mr and Mrs Onorati withheld the final payment of $120,000 of the builder's final fees, demanding that he rectify the defects. Pursuant to a clause of the standard contract this gave the builder the right to take the matter to arbitration, which he did.

SPEECH.PARA: This is where the problems really began. An arbitrator, Mr Donald Bruce Maxwell, was appointed to hear the dispute. Despite the comprehensive report from the Builders Licensing Board and other engineers', builders' and architects' reports specifying the defects and estimating the cost of rectification work at over $500,000, the arbitrator made an award, firstly, that the builder pay Mr and Mrs Onorati $84,000 to cover the cost of rectification, but that the Onoratis pay all the builder's legal costs, totalling some $280,000, the arbitrator's cost of $19,000 with interest at 15 per cent per annum over a three-year period and, on top of that, their own legal costs of some $300,000. Understandably, the Onoratis were astounded, because with the weight of evidence in their favour they had believed it would be an open and shut case. It is incomprehensible to them how the arbitrator on the evidence presented could come to his decision. It seemed to them that he had either failed to realise the significance of or had ignored the advice of independent building and construction experts.

Unfortunately, there is effectively no appeal against this arbitration decision. Like dozens of other people who signed contracts that allow disputes to be heard by arbitration, they naively believed arbitration could be cheaper than a judicial hearing because it could be heard quicker, before a building expert who could see the technical issues, and despite the obligation to pay transcript costs, arbitrators' fees and expenses, in the long run it would be cheaper than taking the case to court. Some four years after first signing the contract and facing debts of almost $1m, Mr and Mrs Onorati have learnt the hard way that arbitration is not as straightforward as it seems. While the builder lost his licence, this is of little consolation to the Onoratis, and in fact the builder is now building again.

Of more concern to this House is what seems to be a growing suspicion amongst people who are the victims of some decisions of arbitrators that these arbitrators, as former builders, may often be in a position to be biased towards their former colleagues, as builders, and those whom consumers are seeking redress against. I gather that it may be possible that at one and the same time a builder may be the owner or director of a building company, the executive of a builders association, a graded arbitrator with the Institute of Arbitrators and, indeed, a director of the Building Services Corporation. So when consumers such as Mr and Mrs Onorati have a complaint to lodge and seek redress from one of these bodies, they may find there is a conflict of interest if one of the people dealing with the application is in fact the builder or, as is more common, one of his colleagues. Although justice may be being done, it is clearly important that it be seen to be done. This may not be the case.

It is also of concern that no formal qualifications are required of arbitrators. An undischarged bankrupt can be an arbitrator; a convicted criminal can be an arbitrator. There is no registry of any Commonwealth court which maintains a registry of arbitrators. On the basis of admissions tabled by the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mr Punch), consumers such as Mr and Mrs Onorati may have valid concerns because their case is not isolated. It seems that arbitration may lead to our jurisprudence being conducted by people who have no legal skills and who may be in a position where they may be biased towards builders, as former builders themselves. It seems very clear that a complete review of the arbitration system is long overdue and that a full inquiry into the Onoratis' case is justified to redress the apparent wrongs which seem to have been done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —`I'm not going to do the spadework for them, but if they get their act together I'm prepared to lead them'. Members of this House may mistakenly believe that that is a quote from the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) which reflects his leadership ambitions, but of course it is nothing other than a claim by Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen that he would be prepared to lead Grey Power at the next election. Of course Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen is clearly in the vanguard of National Party politics. It was only last week in this place that the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford), in an erudite contribution, suggested that the danger was that Grey Power would be hijacked by the coalition. According to the honourable member for Port Adelaide, in South Australia many former Liberal and National Party candidates were part of the Grey Power network. In my home State of Western Australia, the same story occurred at the recent State election. Preferences from Grey Power were directed against sitting Government members, while in the upper House they directed their preferences to the Liberal Party-clearly an expression of their political persuasion. Had they not directed their preferences in that way, had they shared them with the Australian Democrats, they probably would have had a seat in the upper House. That was an error in judgment by Grey Power. Again in Western Australia a large number of ex-Liberal candidates were members of Grey Power and in fact stood in the election for Grey Power.

SPEECH.PARA: Elderly people in this country have legitimate concerns about their future, about their retirement incomes and the sorts of circumstances they will find themselves in in retirement. But we need to look at the facts here. Between March 1983 and December 1988 the consumer price index increased by 49.3 per cent. Average weekly earnings increased by a similar amount, 47.6 per cent, but we find that the pension increased by 60.8 per cent. In real terms there has been a real increase in the pension of 8.3 per cent over our time in government.

Why are pensioners so concerned? Clearly the main reason is disinformation and the hyperbolic commentary on the existing situation. It is the wild, unsubstantiated promises that we are hearing from people such as Grey Power and the Australian Pensioners Party that have led to concern and confusion among pensioners. To its credit, the Liberal Party has now modified the assets test proposals which for a time it was throwing around in this place. It now takes a much more sensible approach to the assets test and to many other reforms introduced by this Government. But that is not for Grey Power or for the Australian Pensioners Party.

Let me give the House a couple of examples. I have in my hand a pamphlet produced before the last election by a Grey Power candidate. He said that he intended to improve pensions by $50 a week. I asked the Parliamentary Library what it would cost to increase the age pension by $50 a week. The answer is that it would cost the Budget $3.5 billion. The second claim was that Grey Power would abolish the means test, the incomes and assets test, just for age pensioners-not for all pensioners, so there will be no equity. Such a proposal would cost $3.17 billion. The total cost of the first two claims-and there are a number of others-is $6.7 billion. The surplus which it has taken us 35 years in this country to establish would be wiped off in one fell swoop by introducing just two of Grey Power's proposals. Clearly it is economic lunacy to suggest that.

I give another example from the Eastern Suburbs Reporter. This is even more a matter of concern, particularly to elderly people in my electorate. The Eastern Suburbs Reporter is a local newspaper circulating in the north of my electorate. This is a claim from the Secretary of the Australian Pensioners Party, Mr Ray Lowe:
When a pensioner dies and his or her house is sold the money recovered goes towards paying back the government for the pension the person has been claiming . . .

Under the heading `Government Grave Robbing' that article appeared, with the suggestion by Mr Lowe that the Government was clawing back from pensioners who had died the pension that they had been paid during their lifetime. There were more claims. Mr Lowe said that the Government saw pensioners as an embarrassment and an encumbrance who were better off dead. Indeed, it is that sort of outlandish, dishonest, distorted and inaccurate suggestion from these people who purport to represent pensioners that has caused confusion and is unfair on pensioners and on this Government. The true story is that pensions have increased in real terms by 8.3 per cent. While the provision for one's retirement is an issue about which pensioners should be concerned, long-term solutions are the answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw to the attention of the House in the few moments that remain the fact that in southern New South Wales at present there is an abattoir strike, a meatworkers strike, taking place.
